story:
From Boston to Fogo Island (a short history)

My name is M’Liz Keefe. I am a painter based in Boston. Two years ago I embarked on a painting expedition to Newfoundland and Labrador.  I was accepted by an artist residency program in the small historic fishing community of Tilting, Fogo Island, off the north-eastern tip of Newfoundland. Since 2013 I have spent close to 18 months painting on the Island.  I have fallen in love with the land and the people and am profoundly inspired by living and painting on the ocean in the raw, inhospitable world of the wild North Atlantic. Working as a painter on the Island has been both a humbling experience and an honor.

What I am doing and why I need your support

This summer will be my 5th trip to Fogo Island. Beginning in July, I will begin an extensive project of 13 large-scale paintings. Each oil painting will be 72 inches x 72 inches square (approx. 183 cm x 183 cm), on stretched canvas. Each painting will represent one of the 11 historic fishing communities on Fogo Island, a painting of nearby Change Islands and one of Little Fogo Islands (abandoned through resettlement in the mid-20th century). All of these communities (except for Little Fogo Islands) are still thriving into the 21st century even after their 300-year-old tradition of cod fishing was devastated by the Cod Moratorium of the 1990s.

Fogo Island is rich in cultural traditions, such as: song, storytelling, music, poetry, quilting, knitting and utilitarian woodworking. There has been little-known documentation of Fogo Island through painting over the centuries, although there are now a few local artists—Winston Osmond among others, whose dedication to depicting life on Fogo Island is beginning to add to the storytelling traditions visually.

In the spirit of The Group of Seven in Canada, and the Hudson River School in the United States, my project is devoted to the landscape and the living history of Fogo Island in the 21st century. Through conversations and direction from the locals, I’ll choose what’s both historically significant and thriving now into the 21st century. Fogo Island is an exciting place to be as it channels its survivalist spirit into creating a vital cultural and historic destination for travelers from around the globe.

From my research, this may very well be the only comprehensive and large scale group of paintings ever done that is solely dedicated to the historic fishing communities of Fogo Island and Change Islands, one of oldest, historically vital and significant outport communities of Newfoundland and Labrador.

Names of the Fishing Communities I will be painting:

Stag Harbor, Seldom, Little Seldom, Tilting, Shoal Bay, Joe Batt’s Arm, Town of Fogo, Deep Bay, Island Harbor, Barr’d Islands, Fogo Central, Change Islands and Little Fogo Islands.

Atlantic Ocean Fogo Island, 2013 Jennifer Keefe House Artist Residency in Tilting oil/wax on canvas 42"x46" (sold)


My studio and living quarters

I’ll be living and painting in the Town of Fogo, the site of Brimstone Head—said to be one of the four corners of the earth by the Flat Earth Society. I’ve rented the old “Pharmacy Building” in the heart of the town, where I’ll have immense wall space and ceiling height. The building is located on Main St, right on the edge of the Atlantic Ocean. The sun will shine through the front windows from the harbor side throughout the long summer days providing lots of natural light. I am planning a four-month stay on the Island July through October (fall being my favorite time of the year there) and aim to complete six of the thirteen paintings. I hope to have the group of thirteen paintings completed within 12-18 months, depending on my scheduled stays on Fogo Island throughout 2015-2016.

My doors will be open daily for locals and tourists to come in and experience the studio and appreciate the artwork, some conversation and a cup o’ tea in one of the most unique places on earth. I also plan to host gatherings for poetry readings, music, storytelling and art shows with other artists’ work. The people of the island are a very close-knit community, and evenings together warm one’s heart and soul with serious laughter, good times, and chatter about the business of life.

Gold Trail, Fogo Island, 42”x46”. Oil, wax, wood stove ashes, powdered asphaltum on canvas. Painted in the Slipway, Tilting in Fall, 2014 (sold)


THE IMPACT OF YOUR DONATIONS AND YOUR "PERKS"

This is the largest and most comprehensive series of paintings I have ever done. Your donation, large or small will help realize their completion.

I am excited about the “perks” I am offering in order to raise the money for this Painting Project. Every piece I paint (including printed thank you notes) will be done by my hand and will be made on Fogo Island this summer. Each of you who donate will have a beautiful painting of a Fogo Island landscape or a painting of the Atlantic Ocean by November/December of this year in your home. I do hope everyone who receives a piece of my work will enjoy years of pleasure with it on your walls and in your life. For more of my work/life/back round please visit my website www.mlizkeefe.com

BUDGET

The money I raise in this campaign goes directly to materials/art supplies for the 13 paintings in The Fogo Island Painting Project and to the shipping costs of the work I complete for this fundraiser.

Each of the 13 paintings will cost conservatively $600.00 in materials. The total cost of materials for all 13 paintings is $7,800.00. Shipping costs are estimated at $2,000.00 if all the artwork/ “perks” I offer here are claimed.

All travel to and from Fogo Island, and living expenses such as food/rent/utilities are covered by me. If I raise over the amount of $10,000.00, every penny will be applied to living/travel expenses on the Island.

 

Risks & Challenges

There are no risks or complications I can think of except of course those unexpected “acts of God” that sometime get in the way of best made plans.

 

 Other Ways You Can Help

I truly believe that contributions to each other’s wishes and needs are varied and meaningful on myriad levels.  Just pass this around to friends and family…..talk about my project to others…think good thoughts...fly a banner off the back of your car….Twitter me to the ends of twitter earth….Indiegogo lets you SHARE from right here….


PERKS.....CHECK THEM OUT!

Here’s a peek at some of my PAINTINGS ON PAPER and PAINTINGS ON CANVAS (all painted on Fogo Island 2013-2014) to let you get a feel for my work and what you will be receiving for your generous donations. 

I will be creating a new series of landscapes and oceans this summer and fall on Fogo Island for everyone here who donates to my campaign!

 

5”x7” oil, wax, wood stove ashes, powdered asphaltum on paper

5”x7” oil, wax, wood stove ashes, powdered asphaltum on paper

 4"x5" oil, wax, woodstove ashes, powdered asphaltum on paper

8"x9" oil, wax, wood stove ashes,powdered asphaltum on paper

Atlantic Ocean II, Fogo Island 2014, 42”x46” oil, wax on canvas

Fogo Island Landscape IV 2014, 20”x20” oil, wax on canvas

Atlantic Ocean VI, Fogo Island 2014, 42”x46” oil, wax on canvas


A Short History of Fogo Island

Fogo Island is the largest, most north-easterly island off Newfoundland. As far back as the 1500s, the island was used by French and Portuguese fishermen during summers because of the great abundance of cod in its waters. English and Irish fishers were the first to create permanent settlements on the island, in the 18th century. 

The Irish are said to have first wintered on the Island in the community of Tilting, in 1752. Fogo Harbor and Tilting Harbor were the first year-round settlements. Listening to many of the locals on the island speak today, one can hear traces of Elizabethan English and Irish-speaking dialects imparted to them across the generations. To this day, both Irish and English descendants retain many of old customs, songs and dances from their ancestral homelands. 

In Tilting the Irish vernacular and Irish ways are particularly distinctive. Tilting is a National Cultural Landscape District of Canada and is Newfoundland and Labrador’s first Provincial Heritage District. It is said to have the oldest Irish Cemetery in North America. By the 1780s it became solely an Irish-Catholic community, and to this day is deeply rooted in this tradition.

During the 1960s, the island, known as an outport, as were all the old fishing communities of Newfoundland and Labrador, was threatened with “resettlement” by the government because of economic unsustainability.  Resettlement meant abandoning the island and resettling on the mainland. During that time the Fogo Island Cooperative was born. The eleven fishing communities on the island joined forces to save the fishing industry of the island.

In 1967, we had to make a life-altering decision on Fogo Island: Leave our beloved island home and resettle on the mainland of Newfoundland and Labrador, or stay and find a way to make it on our own. We stayed and we made it our own. To ensure our survival, we turned to what we knew best for hundreds of years... the sea.

Following a process of community self-discovery, now known worldwide as the Fogo Process, our fishers formed the Fogo Island Co-operative Society, a community based enterprise on which we built the economy of our island. We built more boats. We built bigger boats. We took over processing facilities abandoned by private enterprise. We built more plants. We sought new markets.
—The Co-op

By the 1990s, the cod stock in the Atlantic Ocean had been over-fished and the North Atlantic cod fishing industry had collapsed. The Cod Moratorium of 1992, which limited if not prevented commercial cod fishing entirely, hit East Coast fishing communities hard—Newfoundland in particular. Fogo Island was deeply impacted by the moratorium, as the islanders’ livelihood and their 500-year connection to cod fishing disappeared overnight.

During the ensuing years the Island and the Co-op turned to fishing for other types of seafood, including shrimp and the sea cucumber, which they exported to Asian countries. By the 2000s the population dropped to about 2,500 people from 6,000 in the 1960s. Fogo Island would once again face “life-altering” decisions and need to reinvent itself for the 21st century—this time through embracing eco-tourism and opening its arms to travelers from across the globe.

Through the Shorefast Foundation, a not-for-profit community-based organization founded by philanthropists and entrepreneur sister/brother team Zita and Tony Cobb in the mid-2000s, the Fogo Island Inn was built. Fogo Island has since become a destination for tourists from around the world. Cottage industries are growing, including: small local farming, touring guides, animal husbandry, gift shops, cafes and restaurants, even a coffee bean roaster. Because of Artists residencies on the Island international artists, musicians, and writers come year round to create their work and live among their gracious hosts, the people of Fogo Island.

story:
What artist has made a difference in your life?

We The Artists, 18th Street Arts Center’s first crowdfunding campaign, asks "What artist has made a difference in you life?" of people around the world, because all of us have a story of being inspired by an artist.

But what if those artists were never encouraged or supported? Out of all the funding in Los Angeles county for the arts, only 2% goes to artists. TWO PERCENT. And it's been that way for decades. The rest goes for exhibition-making, schools, etc, but not to the actual people that make the actual art. Just to add to that, a 2003 survey by the Urban Institute found that 97% of people in the US value art as a concept, but only 27% value artists. Those that don't seem to experience a disconnect between living, working artists, and the objects that they appreciate, covet, and want in their homes and museums and on their city streets. As a population, artists are relatively low-paid, precarious workers with very little job stability compared to others of similar education and skills. We need the voices of artists in our world more than ever, and artists need the support of organizations like 18th Street.

This campaign raises funds for a world-class artist residency program, but at 18th Street, we are so much more than that. 18th Street is a place where the public can learn about evolving contemporary artist practices. We commission new artwork and curatorial research and present it in an array of free experimental programs throughout the year. Through artist residencies, exhibitions, print publications, new media platforms and public events, 18th Street has helped over 8,000 artists develop new work and has hosted more that 450 international artists from 54 countries since our founding. By providing space, time, funding, and visibility, we incubate artists so they can create without precarity, make ambitious work and ask big questions. Our goal to raise $30,000 will carry this work into the future.

Artists who come through 18th Street’s residency programs go on to make enormous impacts on their communities. They create astoundingly beautiful work, music, compositions, and performances; they organize; they fight for social justice in creative ways; they work with cities and governments to propose new outside-the-box policy solutions. For many artists, their visit to 18th Street has helped them launch new, award-winning work.

We need your help to ensure that artists’ voices continue to be heard in this world. The funding picture in Los Angeles is extremely difficult for arts organizations, despite all the wealth here, and artists are so often left out. We support 50+ artists a year to experiment, come to LA and make new work, artists that then go on to affect their communities all over the world. We are relying on our community, and those that stand up and support artists, to help us fund our programs for next year.  Think about all the artists who have inspired you. How much richer would our world be, if more artists were supported the way they deserved?

Lita Albuquerque's The Spine of the Earth, 2012

Testimonials about 18th Street (from a visitor survey):

‘One of the only champions for the vanguard voice of artists left in our region. Great service to artists, performers, thinkers.’

“I was offered a solo exhibition there, the first of my art career.  It was a very validating experience, and I am tremendously grateful to the 18th Street Complex for their support. I also met one of the foreign Fellows there who is now one of my best friends. The 18th Street Art Complex is an important creator of community.”

“I find almost every experience at 18th Street to be meaningful...from specific gallery shows, to Art Nights, to performances at Highways Performance Space. There is something to be learned, or something to stimulate the imagination at 18th Street all the time because it is a place where art is made all the time...not just exhibited, but actually created. And it is highly likely that at any one visit, you will meet and artist, or get a glimpse into an artist's studio and start to understand the creative process. This, for me, is a meaningful experience.”

What We Need

18th Street Arts Center is a non-profit, and every year we need to secure nearly one million dollars annually to keep our programs and five buildings running. So much art would not exist if we did not exist.

With your contribution, we will be able to bring dozens of American and international artists to Santa Monica next year to make new artwork, work they will take out into your world--18th Street Arts Center is a vibrant cultural institution serving a global constituency. Join us in elevating the voices of artists around the world. Help this special place of social and civic engagement thrive.

What You Get (The Perks)

As a thank you for your contribution, we have some incredible perks for any level.

  • Weekend as an Artist: You can be an artist-in-residence at 18th Street for a weekend in our artists’ cottage, hang out in beautiful Santa Monica and enjoy dinner and a VIP tour of our campus.
  • Artist-Curated Gift Basket: Famous contemporary artists will personally curate you a creative, inspirational or just wild gift basket. You don't know what you're going to get, only that it's going to be interesting!
  • Studio Visit with a Curator: You can get a studio visit from our distinguished Artistic Director, Anuradha Vikram, who will give you her honest opinions and share all kinds of fascinating stories with you.
  • Artist-Designed Enamel Pins: You won’t want to miss our 5-pack of artist designed enamel pins - it’s the new flag pin. From Candice Lin, Slanguage, Marcus Kuiland-Nazario, Brendan Fernandes, and Amir H. Fallah.
  • WeTheArtists T-shirts are going to be the next big thing. Seriously, you will probably see them in Urban Outfitters tomorrow.
  • Rare Artist Books & Albums: Snag rare High Performance Issues from the 80s and audio editions featuring artists like Mike Kelley, Terry Allen, and Paul McCarthy.

The Impact

In light of the current contentious presidential election, we believe that artists’ voices are more important than ever. After all, 18th Street’s co-founder, Susanna B. Dakin, once ran for president of the United States in the 1984 election in her project An Artist for President. Soon after, she helped found 18th Street Arts Center as a space for the social and civic engagement of artists to thrive, and as a platform for the voices of artists to question, challenge, and propose new possibilities for the world. If we listen to our creativity, think about problems differently, and ask WHY things are the way they are, the world shifts. That, we believe, is what artists can do. It is what artists MUST do.

Susanna B. Dakin runs for President in 1984.

Risks & Challenges

Let’s face it. In a world with as many challenges as ours, the arts are not always prioritized (that’s an understatement). And it is not easy to ask people to support individual artists. Most artists have a really rough time financially. We hear about multi-million dollar paintings selling at auction, rarely to artists benefit from this. 18th Street allows artists to create without fear of financial instability, it provides a foundation and a safety net for their creativity to thrive. It helps amplify and enhance the reach of their work.

We make a difference for artists, and they make a difference in the world. We support artists who:

  • Work with homeless and formerly homeless folks to create theatrical performances and advocate for policy that combats homelessness in LA’s Skid Row. (John Malpede and Henriette Brouwers of Los Angeles Poverty Department, US)
  • Write feminist plays in an oppressive society for women, with great personal risk. (Shahid Nadeem, Pakistan).
  • Worked with the youth of Oakland and the Oakland Police Department to form more human, more understanding relationships through conversation. (Suzanne Lacy, US)
  • Preserve and amplify African indigenous art and work with the Nigerian government on environmental justice (Ofiaeli Okechukwu Okoye, Nigeria)
  • Revealed epidemics of rape across an entire city in a single, poetic installation and performance. (Leslie Labowitz-Starus and Suzanne Lacy, US)
  • Create moving, humorous performances that capture the immigrant experience in America (Dan Kwong, US)
  • Create Emmy-winning films and Grammy-winning compositions (Kate Johnson and Christopher Tin, US)
  • Expose the human costs and irrevocable shifts of landscape in the wake of a brutal dictator (Patricia Fernandez, Spain)

Suzanne Lacy's Code 33 from The Oakland Projects, 1991-2001.

Artists are necessary. They allow us to approach intractable problems with new, poetic solutions. They help us ask, who is not at the table? Whose voices are excluded? They push us to strive for excellence and beauty and poetry and inspiration. We need artists’ voices to resound, not be silenced.

 

Members of the Los Angeles Poverty Department, a theater troupe of homeless and formerly homeless Skid Row residents, run by 18th Street resident artists John Malpede and Henriette Brouwers.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can’t contribute right now, there are many ways to help us reach our goals.

  • Share our Artist Stories series on YouTube where artists tell their stories in their own words.
  • Share this campaign using the Indiegogo social media share tools.
  • Encourage an artist in your life...and make more art!

Thank you!

**18th Street Arts Center is a 501(c)(3) non-profit. Our Federal EIN is 95-3825203.

Those that don't seem to experience a disconnect between living, working artists, and the objects that they appreciate, covet, and want in their homes and museums and on their city streets. As a population, artists are relatively low-paid, precarious workers with very little job stability compared to others of similar education and skills. We need the voices of artists in our world more than ever, and artists need the support of organizations like 18th Street.This campaign raises funds for a world-class artist residency program, but at 18th Street, we are so much more than that. 18th Street is a place where the public can learn about evolving contemporary artist practices. We commission new artwork and curatorial research and present it in an array of free experimental programs throughout the year. Through artist residencies, exhibitions, print publications, new media platforms and public events, 18th Street has helped over 8,000 artists develop new work and has hosted more that 450 international artists from 54 countries since our founding. By providing space, time, funding, and visibility, we incubate artists so they can create without precarity, make ambitious work and ask big questions. Our goal to raise $30,000 will carry this work into the future.Artists who come through 18th Street’s residency programs go on to make enormous impacts on their communities. They create astoundingly beautiful work, music, compositions, and performances; they organize; they fight for social justice in creative ways; they work with cities and governments to propose new outside-the-box policy solutions. For many artists, their visit to 18th Street has helped them launch new, award-winning work.We need your help to ensure that artists’ voices continue to be heard in this world. The funding picture in Los Angeles is extremely difficult for arts organizations, despite all the wealth here, and artists are so often left out. We support 50+ artists a year to experiment, come to LA and make new work, artists that then go on to affect their communities all over the world. We are relying on our community, and those that stand up and support artists, to help us fund our programs for next year.  Think about all the artists who have inspired you. How much richer would our world be, if more artists were supported the way they deserved?Lita Albuquerque's The Spine of the Earth, 2012Testimonials about 18th Street (from a visitor survey):‘One of the only champions for the vanguard voice of artists left in our region. Great service to artists, performers, thinkers.’“I was offered a solo exhibition there, the first of my art career.  It was a very validating experience, and I am tremendously grateful to the 18th Street Complex for their support. I also met one of the foreign Fellows there who is now one of my best friends. The 18th Street Art Complex is an important creator of community.”“I find almost every experience at 18th Street to be meaningful...from specific gallery shows, to Art Nights, to performances at Highways Performance Space. There is something to be learned, or something to stimulate the imagination at 18th Street all the time because it is a place where art is made all the time...not just exhibited, but actually created. And it is highly likely that at any one visit, you will meet and artist, or get a glimpse into an artist's studio and start to understand the creative process. This, for me, is a meaningful experience.”What We Need18th Street Arts Center is a non-profit, and every year we need to secure nearly one million dollars annually to keep our programs and five buildings running. So much art would not exist if we did not exist.With your contribution, we will be able to bring dozens of American and international artists to Santa Monica next year to make new artwork, work they will take out into your world--18th Street Arts Center is a vibrant cultural institution serving a global constituency. Join us in elevating the voices of artists around the world. Help this special place of social and civic engagement thrive.What You Get (The Perks)As a thank you for your contribution, we have some incredible perks for any level.

Weekend as an Artist: You can be an artist-in-residence at 18th Street for a weekend in our artists’ cottage, hang out in beautiful Santa Monica and enjoy dinner and a VIP tour of our campus.

Artist-Curated Gift Basket: Famous contemporary artists will personally curate you a creative, inspirational or just wild gift basket. You don't know what you're going to get, only that it's going to be interesting!

Studio Visit with a Curator: You can get a studio visit from our distinguished Artistic Director, Anuradha Vikram, who will give you her honest opinions and share all kinds of fascinating stories with you.

Artist-Designed Enamel Pins: You won’t want to miss our 5-pack of artist designed enamel pins - it’s the new flag pin. From Candice Lin, Slanguage, Marcus Kuiland-Nazario, Brendan Fernandes, and Amir H. Fallah.

WeTheArtists T-shirts are going to be the next big thing. Seriously, you will probably see them in Urban Outfitters tomorrow.

Rare Artist Books & Albums: Snag rare High Performance Issues from the 80s and audio editions featuring artists like Mike Kelley, Terry Allen, and Paul McCarthy.
The ImpactIn light of the current contentious presidential election, we believe that artists’ voices are more important than ever. After all, 18th Street’s co-founder, Susanna B. Dakin, once ran for president of the United States in the 1984 election in her project An Artist for President. Soon after, she helped found 18th Street Arts Center as a space for the social and civic engagement of artists to thrive, and as a platform for the voices of artists to question, challenge, and propose new possibilities for the world. If we listen to our creativity, think about problems differently, and ask WHY things are the way they are, the world shifts. That, we believe, is what artists can do. It is what artists MUST do.Susanna B. Dakin runs for President in 1984.Risks & ChallengesLet’s face it. In a world with as many challenges as ours, the arts are not always prioritized (that’s an understatement). And it is not easy to ask people to support individual artists. Most artists have a really rough time financially. We hear about multi-million dollar paintings selling at auction, rarely to artists benefit from this. 18th Street allows artists to create without fear of financial instability, it provides a foundation and a safety net for their creativity to thrive. It helps amplify and enhance the reach of their work.We make a difference for artists, and they make a difference in the world. We support artists who:
Work with homeless and formerly homeless folks to create theatrical performances and advocate for policy that combats homelessness in LA’s Skid Row. (John Malpede and Henriette Brouwers of Los Angeles Poverty Department, US)
Write feminist plays in an oppressive society for women, with great personal risk. (Shahid Nadeem, Pakistan).
Worked with the youth of Oakland and the Oakland Police Department to form more human, more understanding relationships through conversation. (Suzanne Lacy, US)
Preserve and amplify African indigenous art and work with the Nigerian government on environmental justice (Ofiaeli Okechukwu Okoye, Nigeria)
Revealed epidemics of rape across an entire city in a single, poetic installation and performance. (Leslie Labowitz-Starus and Suzanne Lacy, US)
Create moving, humorous performances that capture the immigrant experience in America (Dan Kwong, US)
Create Emmy-winning films and Grammy-winning compositions (Kate Johnson and Christopher Tin, US)
Expose the human costs and irrevocable shifts of landscape in the wake of a brutal dictator (Patricia Fernandez, Spain)
Suzanne Lacy's Code 33 from The Oakland Projects, 1991-2001.Artists are necessary. They allow us to approach intractable problems with new, poetic solutions. They help us ask, who is not at the table? Whose voices are excluded? They push us to strive for excellence and beauty and poetry and inspiration. We need artists’ voices to resound, not be silenced. Members of the Los Angeles Poverty Department, a theater troupe of homeless and formerly homeless Skid Row residents, run by 18th Street resident artists John Malpede and Henriette Brouwers. Other Ways You Can HelpIf you can’t contribute right now, there are many ways to help us reach our goals.

Share our Artist Stories series on YouTube where artists tell their stories in their own words.

Share this campaign using the Indiegogo social media share tools.

Encourage an artist in your life...and make more art!
Thank you!**18th Street Arts Center is a 501(c)(3) non-profit. Our Federal EIN is 95-3825203.

story:
Help Complete the Deez Jr. homage to Waterworld!


A few months ago, I ran a fundraiser to help save parts of the Exxon Valdez model from Waterworld.  While I was initially attempting to raise $5000, I was able to figure out how to build the movable homage to the Sci Fi film for $2500.   As it turned out, we raised almost $3000!  If you were one of the contributors, thank you!

I, and a bunch of fellow filmmakers and film fans buckled down and built the stern of "The Deez Jr." in 4 weeks.  It has turned out extremely well.  It measures 30' in length and is about 25' tall to the top of the smoke stake.  There is a top VIP deck for people who contributed to the fundraiser and are attending Wasteland Weekend 2015 and much of the side of the ship are the exact panels in the exact positions they were in on the original Exxon Valdez ship in Waterworld!

There stern of the " boat" is now finished (see pic above), dock materials have  been purchased, as has a trailer for the skeletal frame of the bow.  Unfortunately, due to design changes involving how the original model was built and issues with mounting and covering the bow, we are seeking additional funds to complete the project.

We are looking to raise $1,500 in additional funds.  The contributions will go to purchase 2" tube metal and welding supplies to make support beams to mount the bow frame to the trailer, luan wood (a thin sheet of wood used in set building) to cover the entire bow with to provide a material to screw and staple the original metal skin too, 12 sheets of 3/4 inch plywood to make the top deck, 2 x 10 to make a  set of stairs leading up onto the deck, and stands and safety chain to make safety rails on the deck.  The money will go directly to supplies.

This fundraiser is a short one.  Two weeks, as we have to have the complete boat built in three, in time for Wasteland Weekend 2014!  All the perks on the original fundraiser are available now, including the very popular $5 dollar perk which gives you access to a private video of the ship and the colorful characters of the Pirates of the Arid Seas and a behind the scenes look at the 2nd Annual Post Apocalyptic Swimsuit Fashion Show!

If you already have contributed, please give a little more to show your support to this amazing project.  And if you haven't contributed, pick a perk and join in on the fun!  There are some great perks you can get whether you attend Wasteland Weekend or not!

And if you can't assist financially, if you are a welder or construction person, come on out and join us on the weekend to build and become part of the Pirates of the Arid Seat crew members!  If you don't have build skills, you can still assist us by spreading the word and urging others to contribute!

Please help the Pirates of the Arid Seas correctly finish a very cool  homage to Waterworld and create quite a large stage for the post apocalyptic swimsuit fashion show!

Thank You Very Much,

Paul Miller
"The Duke of the Deez"
Pirate of the Arid Seas.

story:
Our Story

" Where the spirit does not work with the hands, there is no art." - Leonardo da Vinci

I have always known that artistry lies inherent in me and over the years it too is innate in my kids. So its no surprise that I have made a living in such a field and my kids got acclaim doing so in their own respective school. We want to keep drawing, painting, creating. And we want to share it through a media that will sustain our pursuits. What more perfect enterprise to share our love of art than to have it as a  wearable. We as a family have focused our sights on achieving this goal. To design to our hearts delight and have it realized with quality .

And so we venture into this business model of wearable art and custom apparels. We are now in the process of stocking our inventory, offering to the public custom designs for shirts, jackets and other clothing line. A dream fueled by art.

Our Mission

"The disparity between what schools offer and what students actually receive can be enormous, Some of those students are going to get music and some of those students aren't."- Richard Kessler, Dean of Mannes College The New School of Music and former Executive Director of The Center for Arts Education.

See Huffington Post blog below;

http://www.huffingtonpost.com/yohuru-williams/rhythm-and-bruise-how-cut_b_5838406.html

With your support we'd like to show you who we are and what we're passionate at.

We would like to call awareness and appreciation to music & the arts in public schools and its after-school programs.  Over the years public schools in the United States have lessened their focus on the arts & music, In some cases it relies on private funding to keep these activities going, programs fueled only by eager parents, fantastic teachers, private pockets and hard working kids. We as parents of kids who are in these programs would like to extend our support using our venture as a platform.

The music line of graphic tees is intended to bring about a visual display of awareness and appreciation to these performance arts. A tenth of the proceeds of this campaign will go to our local public school music and band programs. We also hope that this campaign will bring about new found zest and vigor for the public to extend aid to this cause. We try and do what little we can.

Wear Art for Music.


Our Dream


We are Wear Art Designs- www.wearartdesigns.net . A small business making its way to fulfilling a dream.

We were fortunate to have the friendship and manufacturing arm of LGR Athletics Wear Inc. - www.lgrsportswear.com . Fortunate to use the Philippines premier sportswear and graphic tees manufacturer on our side, to produce quality products that fulfills our design vision.

Wear Art Designs  would like to grow, with your support, we aim to create a dynamic online presence showcasing varied design series focused on music, sports, fashion and the arts. And continue supporting our community where it counts.


Perks

To help support our campaign there are 9 Music Series T-shirts to chose from, please purchase one and your contribution will go a long way in making these a reality.





Tshirt Sizes


XS - 36" chest, 25"/26" length, 16-1/2" shoulder, 7-1/2" sleeves

Small - 38" chest, 26"/27" length, 17" shoulder, 8" sleeves

Medium - 40" chest, 27"/28" length, 17-1/2" shoulder, 8-1/2" sleeves

Large - 42" chest, 28"/29" length, 18" shoulder, 9" sleeves

XL - 44" chest, 29"30" length, 18-1/2" shoulder, 9-1/2" sleeves

2XL- 46" chest, 30"/31" length, 19" shoulder, 10" sleeves

3 XL- 48" chest, 31"32" length, 19-1/2" shoulder, 10-1/2" sleeves

Tshirts are graphically represented above.

Actual  Sample of Shirt




Funding Breakdown

Target Goal = $10,000

40% - Production of t-shirts, materials, shipping = $4,000

10%- Public school after school music program support = $1,000

4%- Indiegogo Fee (upon reaching goal) = $400

5%- Credit Card Fees = $500

41%- Online store inventory = $4,100


FAQs

1. What is Crowdfunding?

  The practice of funding a project or venture by raising many small amounts of money from a large number of people, typically via the internet.

http://www.forbes.com/sites/tanyaprive/2012/11/...

2. What is Indiegogo?

  This is the crowdfunding platform we are using for our "Wear art for Music" campaign. To know more about this platform see Terms of Use below. 

https://www.indiegogo.com/about/terms

3. How does it work?

  Simply look and read through our campaign, if you like it and eager to support it because you believe in the cause and the mission, or maybe even like the perks, you can choose from a list of Perks listed and Support the cause. For more see below.

  https://support.indiegogo.com/hc/en-us

3. What is "Wear Art for Music" ?

  The theme "Wear Art for Music" stems from a question, "where are we as a society in growing our youth?" Where is the arts, where is music?

  Its a theme propagated for appreciation & awareness by a media using wearable art, hence Wear Art.

4. Who are we supporting?

  You are supporting a small business venture named Wear Art Designs LLC. - www.wearartdesigns.net. We specialize in sportswear for team sports, and custom designed apparels. We've only began our start-up here in California early part of this year 2015. Currently in the process of marketing and spreading the word. Also building our online presence to be a dynamic web store for custom designed clothing, this is where you come in. We need assistance in financing some of our design series to be featured in the online store.

  LGR Athletics Wear Inc - www.lgrsportswear.com, A established 20 plus year old company based in Manila specializing in quality sportswear gave us a leg up by allowing our LLC to use their manufacturing arm to produce our designs with their quality products.

https://ph.sports.yahoo.com/blogs/thepassionatefan/inside-azkals-kit-supplier-083457590.html

  We used the business for awareness campaign approach of Arts & Music because we as parents are heavily involved in our kids education and activities. The school community of Chino Valley , San Bernardino County California is renowned for supporting a big music and performance band group mostly privately funded, so here we are extending our financial support, and with your help we'll be doing it as a community.

5. What are the Perks?

  Mostly quality designed t-shirts. Made of 100% cotton material round neck, tailored and produced in-house by LGR in Manila carrying the company tag. The prints are hand drawn and computer enhanced, designed here in California, printed using rubberized paint.

  Upon successful completion of the 30 day campaign, we will receive the funding after 15 days, we will then after start production of these shirts (30 days projection) to be shipped to your address by August, ( Free shipping in US cities, we'll have to add shipping cost for those outside the US).  You will be informed of the progress and the stage we are in the campaign. And with it is our heartfelt thanks and gratitude in allowing a small business like us to get a jumpstart in these competitive field. Thank you.

story: We wanted to use Bismuth to create different types of trinkets due to its beautiful natural formations. The Skull is our first idea, but we've only been able to make a skull half the size we are shooting for. So we need more Bismuth to make this a reality!
story_txt: We wanted to use Bismuth to create different types of trinkets due to its beautiful natural formations. The Skull is our first idea, but we've only been able to make a skull half the size we are shooting for. So we need more Bismuth to make this a reality!

story:
The Project (video transcript)

Hello, I’m Erin Taylor. You may recognize my work from Artica festival in St. Louis or BLINK festival in Cincinnati. I’ve been making large scale art installations for over a decade.

In 2010 at Artica, the St. Louis based urban arts festival, I created a camera obscura viewing room using twenty repurposed 35mm camera lenses. This year for the 2018 Foto Focus Biennial in Cincinnati, I will be be building a refined version of this project called Domus Oculi. It is a freestanding 10’ x 10’ octagon shaped structure that will have a camera obscura viewing device on each of the walls. These camera obscuras will be created using lenses from film cameras, enlargers and slide projectors. This work acts as a counterpoint to the barrage of images we encounter in our digital landscape and redirects our attention to the world around us.

Currently I am in the the middle of fabrication after a year-long design process. The camera obscura devices that were designed in CAD are being 3d printed. Parts for the metal roof framing are being cut, ground and welded. The wooden wall framing is being cut and screwed together, soon to be painted. My plan is to start assembling the project at the site by the end of this month.

You can experience Domus Oculi every Friday, Saturday and Sunday in the month of October. The best part is admission is free.

I have received a grant from the Foto Focus organization that covers a portion of the project expenses. Your generous support to this campaign will help cover additional cost. Any size donation is welcome. Please check out the wide variety of project perks. You can also contribute by sharing and liking the project on social media.  Thank you for your support.

Domus Oculi, FotoFocus Biennial, 2018.

Preliminary design drawing, 42" x36".

 

How is my contribution used?

This campaign is looking to raise one-third of the thirty-two hundred dollars required to finish the project. I'm hoping to exceed this goal. All of the additional funds will come from me personally. 

What your contribution helps cover:

  • Engineering consultation fees. $750
  • Custom fabricated canopy. $1000
  • Building permit and associated cost. $150
  • Production cost of crowdsource premiums. 
  • Crowdsource service fees and shipping. 

What has already been covered by my grant from FotoFocus:

  • Materials including wood, metal, biodegradable 3D printing plastic, and hardware.
  • Outsourced fabrication of plasma cutting.
  • The free festival I am throwing for the Camp Washington community is called ‘Eyes on Camp.’ This includes live music, food, as well as two portable trailer museums.

Personal contribution:

  • Over 2000 hours of research, design, prototyping, and fabrication. I’m doing as much of the fabrication as possible. This includes 3D printing, woodworking, and welding.
  • Organizing the community festival ‘Eyes on Camp.’ 
  • Buying materials and fabricating a stage for the ‘Eyes on Camp’ festival. This stage will be donated to PAR-Projects, a local non-profit arts group, after the festival for years of use.
  • Design cost for logo, posters, and T-shirts.
  • Purchasing and use of a 3D printer that has logged a couple hundred hours of prints. These parts are used for the camera obscura viewing devices.
  • Lots of tools. Some purchased specifically to facilitate the fabrication of the project.
  • Hundreds of miles driven to acquire supplies.
  • I commissioned a custom mural by local artist Mark Specker that will be visible from the camera obscura as well as engage the neighborhood beyond the life of the project.

 

Impact

This is the largest and most ambitious project I’ve ever done and I’m almost finished. I look forward to having thousands of people visit and engage with this unique camera obscura installation during the FotoFocus 2018 Biennial. My goal is to reach both those familiar with camera obscuras as well as those who have never been able to experience one in person. This project along with the accompanying community festival I am throwing will be a great opportunity to engage with people of all ages.

You can visit my website at www.studioerintaylor.com to see more of my past work.

 

You can also help by… spreading the word of both this campaign and the project in general. Please use the Idiegogo share tools to help post to Facebook, Instagram, and Twitter. If you see a post, please hit ‘like’ and comment. Check in frequently for updates.
story_txt:
The Project (video transcript)Hello, I’m Erin Taylor. You may recognize my work from Artica festival in St. Louis or BLINK festival in Cincinnati. I’ve been making large scale art installations for over a decade.In 2010 at Artica, the St. Louis based urban arts festival, I created a camera obscura viewing room using twenty repurposed 35mm camera lenses. This year for the 2018 Foto Focus Biennial in Cincinnati, I will be be building a refined version of this project called Domus Oculi. It is a freestanding 10’ x 10’ octagon shaped structure that will have a camera obscura viewing device on each of the walls. These camera obscuras will be created using lenses from film cameras, enlargers and slide projectors. This work acts as a counterpoint to the barrage of images we encounter in our digital landscape and redirects our attention to the world around us.Currently I am in the the middle of fabrication after a year-long design process. The camera obscura devices that were designed in CAD are being 3d printed. Parts for the metal roof framing are being cut, ground and welded. The wooden wall framing is being cut and screwed together, soon to be painted. My plan is to start assembling the project at the site by the end of this month.You can experience Domus Oculi every Friday, Saturday and Sunday in the month of October. The best part is admission is free.I have received a grant from the Foto Focus organization that covers a portion of the project expenses. Your generous support to this campaign will help cover additional cost. Any size donation is welcome. Please check out the wide variety of project perks. You can also contribute by sharing and liking the project on social media.  Thank you for your support.Domus Oculi, FotoFocus Biennial, 2018.Preliminary design drawing, 42" x36". How is my contribution used?This campaign is looking to raise one-third of the thirty-two hundred dollars required to finish the project. I'm hoping to exceed this goal. All of the additional funds will come from me personally. What your contribution helps cover:
Engineering consultation fees. $750
Custom fabricated canopy. $1000
Building permit and associated cost. $150
Production cost of crowdsource premiums. 
Crowdsource service fees and shipping. 
What has already been covered by my grant from FotoFocus:
Materials including wood, metal, biodegradable 3D printing plastic, and hardware.
Outsourced fabrication of plasma cutting.
The free festival I am throwing for the Camp Washington community is called ‘Eyes on Camp.’ This includes live music, food, as well as two portable trailer museums.
Personal contribution:
Over 2000 hours of research, design, prototyping, and fabrication. I’m doing as much of the fabrication as possible. This includes 3D printing, woodworking, and welding.
Organizing the community festival ‘Eyes on Camp.’ 
Buying materials and fabricating a stage for the ‘Eyes on Camp’ festival. This stage will be donated to PAR-Projects, a local non-profit arts group, after the festival for years of use.
Design cost for logo, posters, and T-shirts.
Purchasing and use of a 3D printer that has logged a couple hundred hours of prints. These parts are used for the camera obscura viewing devices.
Lots of tools. Some purchased specifically to facilitate the fabrication of the project.
Hundreds of miles driven to acquire supplies.
I commissioned a custom mural by local artist Mark Specker that will be visible from the camera obscura as well as engage the neighborhood beyond the life of the project.
 ImpactThis is the largest and most ambitious project I’ve ever done and I’m almost finished. I look forward to having thousands of people visit and engage with this unique camera obscura installation during the FotoFocus 2018 Biennial. My goal is to reach both those familiar with camera obscuras as well as those who have never been able to experience one in person. This project along with the accompanying community festival I am throwing will be a great opportunity to engage with people of all ages.You can visit my website at www.studioerintaylor.com to see more of my past work. You can also help by… spreading the word of both this campaign and the project in general. story:
Short Summary

Hello, I'm Megan Charland. I'm producing and co-curating an experimental dinner event, The Civil Appetites, on May 3, 2013 with the research and design collaborative spurse. We are inviting participants to join us in a meal and conversation about food culture.  

The Civil Appetites is in conjunction with the exhibition Eat It at Rochester Contemporary Art Center (RoCo) April 4 - May 12, 2013. While our dinner event takes place towards the end of the exhibition, we will have an installation up at RoCo for the duration of Eat It to compliment, and lead up to, our event. The Civil Appetites is co-curated by Matthew Friday.  

The dinner event (May 3, 2013) is taking place during First Friday and we invite the public to stop in and participate!

I am thrilled to bring spurse to Rochester, NY and now am seeking your help to financially make it happen.

What We Need

The funds raised during this campaign will be used towards supplies for the exhibition and dinner event as well as providing an honorarium for spurse. Any additional funds raised will increase the honorarium for spurse going towards travel costs (to Rochester, NY). 

 

Above: sketch of Collaborator Tote Bag

What You Get

Thank you for your support! To show our appreciation, we have the following gifts:

  • $5 - The Minor Act of Re-Inscription Kit 
  • $10 - Interventionist Kit
  • $25 - Collaborator Tote Bag
  • $35 - Eat Your Sidewalk Poster
  • $75 - The Sidewalk Insurrectionist

Apart from the tote bag, designed by Megan Charland (handprinted by Hey Buddy!), all gifts are from spurse. 

The Impact

The Civil Appetites would increase civic participation, environmental awareness and help produce new models of responsible thinking and being in the world. This event will be widely publicized, with the potential to bring a diverse community into contact with the amazing work being done in Rochester around the issues of food culture. 

Who, or rather what is spurse?

Spurse is a research and design collaborative that catalyzes critical issues into collective action. Through a playful transformation of conceptual and material systems, we develop problems worth having and worlds worth making, engaging across scales and complexities of all things human and nonhuman, organic and non- organic. We begin every endeavor by locating ourselves of the world, not merely in the world. Spurse has an extensive amount of experience in designing educational community service events that bring together multiple stakeholders with the aim of making a positive difference in the world. Central to our mission is to creatively rethink how citizens can become aware of their position in ecological networks across multiple scales of temporality and spatiality. We have designed numerous public events that bring together diverse stakeholders and have collaborated with large-scale NGOs such as the North Atlantic Marine Alliance, the Riverkeepers and Rural Action. Our work emphasizes ecological dynamics, critical thinking and education for sustainability. To learn more about us see: www.spurse.org.

Invitation from spurse

Please accept our invitation for dinner.
To eat more than you can: Ideas, Practices and Foods.
To give more than you know. 

We wish to explore and invent with you a world that is already everywhere: the commons. 

We wish to explore and invent with you a world that is still to come: the commons.

And yes, we can go on and tell you about all that is wrong with our food practices -- how we eat is literally killing us and the planet. But you know all that. So enough said. What should we do? Again, as you taught us, this is the wrong question. 

What are we already doing? What are you doing?
We are interested in your practices.
We are interested in what is everywhere -- the commons.
We are interested in what is almost nowhere: subsistence. 

And so we invite you to an experimental dinner event The Civil Appetites, aimed at exploring future food ways and commons. What we can offer: a meal that radically fuses experimental practices of gathering, cooking, serving and talking. 

We look forward to spending the evening with you and seeing what could happen next! 

THANK YOU

THANK YOU for your support! Please use the Indiegogo share tools to share this campaign with your friends, family, and colleagues!

story:
"Feel the FABRIC...Embrace the CULTURE"

Hi, I'm Lisa Shepard Stewart of Cultured Expressions, and this October I'll be hosting my third group tour to Ghana, West Africa, designed especially for fabric and bead lovers!  A major part of this year's Experience is Cultured Expressions' first fiber art exhibit, which will take place IN GHANA during our trip.

About the EXHIBIT

I really wanted to do something different from the 2010 and 2011 Ghana tours, and it was in the midst of the 2011 tour that I decided it was time for Cultured Expressions (CE) to curate its first fiber art exhibit there, showcasing what?...  African Fabrics!  The juicy, authentic stuff -- wax batiks, African cotton prints, kente cloth, bogolan / mudcloth, kuba raffia, adire, adinkra stamping...The theme of the exhibit became "SewJourn to Ghana: Contemporary Quilts from Traditional Textiles"


The idea first came to me during our visit to the Dei Centre, a leading contemporary African art gallery in Tesano (Accra), Ghana.  I casually planted the idea in the ear of the gallery owner, Mr. Dei himself! You know the feeling when your vision is crystal clear and all you have to do is make it happen?
Through the tours, it's always been my vision to facilitate a cultural exchange among creative people here the US and in Ghana, through its fabrics and crafts.  Furthering this vision, the "SewJourn" exhibit will give viewers an appreciation for these culturally relevant, visually exciting traditional textiles, as interpreted by contemporary quilters.  The exhibit takes place October 13-28, 2013.


So, I put out the Call to Artists for quilts & fiber art to be exhibited, with enthusiastic responses from some of this year's trip participants, some former participants, other friends of CE, and a few Ghana-based fiber artists as well.  About forty quilts later, I'm now in the next phase of "making it happen" -- and it's "happening" all over my office:  shipping quotes;  artist applications and photos; insurance contacts; notes-to-self on the perfect fonts for the printed materials; reminders about PR contacts in Ghana; links to slideshow software -- I think you get the idea!

Become a PARTNER in the SewJourn

It's quite an experience so far...Brain-draining?  Yes!  A little scary?  Yes!  Exhilarating? Yes!  Worthwhile?  Absolutely!  Oh, and did I mention the costs? This is where your partnership comes in -- I invite you become an integral part of CE's first fiber art exhibit. Funding will help to facilitate everything:

  • shipping and insurance costs
  • gallery costs
  • opening reception
  • printed materials and marketing

 

Now...About the PERKS!

I welcome you as a partner in this artistic vision, at whatever level you see fit, and I look forward to fulfilling your chosen Perk afterwards. If you love the fabrics, but not so much the sewing, choose one of the handcrafted items, designed and sewn by me as a personal Thank-You.  Or, if you love to create your own, enlist some of your creative pals (but only the fun ones!) to take advantage of one of my hands-on workshop rewards- it's a unique DIY experience you won't forget, perfect for beginners and experienced quilters & crafters alike.


Please feel free to contact me with any questions, and to share the SewJourn campaign with others. Of course, if you are in Accra on the evening of Monday, October 13, I welcome you to attend the opening reception!

On behalf of CE and all of the participating artists, I THANK YOU for your time and interest.

story:
Hi-
If you live in Santa Fe, you probably know us, or have seen our shiny aluminum mobile gallery, Axle Contemporary, on the streets of the city for the past three years.  If you live elsewhere, you might have read about us in the national press.
We occasionally create artworks which move beyond the mobile gallery.  The Renga Project is one of these.  It brings the poetry of 49 New Mexico poets to the public on a changing sign in downtown Santa Fe. It then engages 52 visual artist who respond to the stanzas with a linked series of drawings which we'll publish with the finished poem, as a book.  The Renga Project is inspired by the great sucess of our Haiku Roadsign project, from 2011.

The year-long Renga Project will expose thousands to a  public art and poetry collaboration created by over 100 people.

On June 21st, 2013, we'll install a beautiful wooden signboard, complete with a small roof near the corner of Guadalupe Street and Cerrillos Road, in the Railyard Park in Santa Fe.  Each week we’ll hang a new stanza on the sign.  Renga is an ancient traditional  collaborative form of poetry from Japan.  Poets write short stanzas which respond to what has come before.  Our Renga will be written by 49 New Mexico poets.  Santa Fe’s Poet Laureate Jon Davis will start each of the four seasonal sections.  The other stanzas will be written by 24 poets selected by him and an additional 24 poets selected by them.  There will be 6 stanzas at a time on the sign.  As each new stanza is added, the oldest will be removed.  The public will experience, over the course of a year, a changing and evolving 52 stanza collaborative poem.
In addition, we’ll invite 52 New Mexico Artists to create a linked drawing which illustrates the poem.  We’ll publish a book at the close of the project with the full poem and the full linked drawing.  There are 3 versions of the book, an affordable paperback, a series of four seasonal handmade miniature japanese-style folded books, and a beautiful limited edition handmade accordion book.  All of this will culminate with a reading of the poem with the poets at the New Mexico Museum of Art and an exhibition of the drawings in the Axle Contemporary mobile gallery in the summer of 2014.

We need to raise a minimum of $1,500 to fund this project.  This will help pay for the construction and installation of the sign, the large-format printing of the stanzas, the weekly installation work, the design and printing of the book, organizational duties, and a copy of the book for each of the poets and artists. 


Please contribute to help us make this project.  And spread the word to let others know about it.

 

Thank you!

 

Matthew Chase-Daniel and Jerry Wellman,

Axle Contemporary

 

Find out more about Axle Contemporary and Jerry and Matthew here:  www.axleart.com

story:
MadRat Bevco, is passionate about giving back to our community.  As we planned to launch our company to the public, we realized we could raise money, awareness & support for a local community organization.  After learning of local public school, Garden Oaks Magnet Montessori's loss of art and music funding, we decided to do something BIG! #HHFGH was born!!  Our desire to give back is being fulfilled and we are enthusiastically partnering with Garden Oaks to inspire children to live healthy, creative lives while following their Heart's Desires!

#HHFGH campaign was born from the compassionate hearts of MadRat Bevco Team-members and their desire to Make A Difference in their community.  


Our primary goal is to raise $288,422 & raise awareness of the mass cuts to public school art, creativity, health and music programs.  The funds are allocated to:

1.  10% - Garden Oaks Creativity Festival, a festival to inspire the students to find their passion and engage in art & creativity programs

2. 40% - Create art, health & creativity programs at Garden Oaks Magnet Montessori

3. 40% - #MADenergy Launch Party & Fundraiser for Garden Oaks Magnet Montessori

4.  5% - Supplies

5.  5% - Marketing & PR of the events and programs


The impact your donation has on the students of Garden Oaks is tremendous. Kids require creative outlets! Imagine what school would have been like without any art or music classes? No band? No painting, drawing, coloring?  No place for creative expression!  Removing these creativity programs from the school experience affects students' involvement and ability to truly learn.  In the past, most of the elementary school education revolved around some sort of artistic activity. The Garden Oaks School has little to no district funding for these areas of education.   Every aspect of their arts programs are currently being generously donated by parents, teachers, volunteers and the community.  Please support us in making a longterm difference in their lives. Have a hand in shaping their futures! You will also be giving a helping hand to MadRat Bevco, a company that believes success is directly attributed to the health and prosperity of their customers and community!

“And the day came when the risk to remain tight in a bud was more painful than the risk it took to blossom.”― Anaïs Nin

“A ship is safe in harbor, but that's not what ships are for.”― William G.T. Shedd

“Only those who will risk going too far can possibly find out how far one can go.”― T.S. Eliot

“Life is either a daring adventure or nothing at all.”― Helen Keller

“Risks must be taken because the greatest hazard in life is to risk nothing.”― Leo Buscaglia

“Do not stop thinking of life as an adventure. You have no security unless you can live bravely, excitingly, imaginatively; unless you can choose a challenge instead of competence.”― Eleanor Roosevelt


Honestly, you don't need money to still be a valuable asset to our campaign.  When you become aware of our cause, please forward the message to your friends and family. Simply spreading the word is just as important as the donations themselves! The Indiegogo staff thought about this, and kindly provided us all with tools throughout the site to share this wonderful content.  Also, if you live in the Houston area and would like to donate art supplies or your time to teach art, music, creativity, health, wellness, etc.., we are honored to facilitate your involvement.

We are so blessed to have an energetic, inspired team of compassionate individuals who believe in the power of creativity!  We have a shared vision and belief in dreaming BIG!  We also have a lot of FUN!

The Casey Family - Founders of MadRat Bevco
Payten, Kristal, Zayne & Dwayne 

Alisha Cunningham - Garden Oaks Liaison, Mother of 2 Garden Oaks Students, #MADfan & The Glue That Binds Us Together :)
Claudia De Velaso - Founder of Day To Remember, #HHFGH UH-Mazing Event Planner & Director of MADfun!
Bianca Bucaram - Co-Founder of Zapatero + Bucaram Public Relations, #HHFGH Spectacular Publicist & Genius Promoter with #MADheart <3

Austin Potts - Our "Right Hand Man", Cheerleader, Promoter & Lover of all things #MadRat

Trevor Gazaway - #MADsupporter & Promo Team-member

Alex Kaplan - #Elixr Enthusiast & Promo Team-member



MadRat Bevco is a holistic, healthy beverage company founded by Dwayne & Kristal Casey. Together, they created the first truly holistic energy drink, Elixr, made & manufactured deep in the heart of Texas!  Elixr supports MadRat Bevco’s goal - create healthy beverages that increase energy, inspire creativity and encourage bliss. Their passion to spread health, creativity and happiness is a driving force in their business!


These pioneers of healthy energy have set their sights on contributing to the community, by partnering with the Garden Oaks Magnet Montessori, an HISD school, to help raise money for their creativity and health programs.The MadRat Bevco team believes wholeheartedly that their own success is dependent on a prosperous and energetic world. They desire you to join them in bettering the world together! Through great energy, health and happiness!

We desire to extend our heartfelt thanks and #MADgratitude to our family, friends, supporters, fans & customers.  Your belief in us has given us the energy to pursue our dreams.  We are grateful beyond words and honored to have you all in our lives. Special thanks to:

Dr. Lindsey Pollock, Principal, Garden Oaks Magnet Montessori
Alisha Cunningham, PTO Liaison, Garden Oaks Magnet Montessori
Barbie Atkinson, PTO President, Garden Oaks Magnet Montessori
Toni Valle, PTO Arts & Enrichment Chair, Garden Oaks Magnet Montessori
Steve & Karen Cline, Karen Cline Realtors
Preston Kiser, CHIEFDOODLE Productions
Bianca Bucaram & Jessica Zapatero, Zapatero + Bucaram Public Relations 
Claudia De Velasco, A Day To Remember Event Planning
Robert Thompson
Anita Scanlan
And countless others who have loved and supported us!  May God bless you all beyond your wildest dreams!!

#HHFGH campaign was born from the compassionate hearts of MadRat Bevco Team-members and their desire to Make A Difference in their community.  










Our primary goal is to raise $288,422 & raise awareness of the mass cuts to public school art, creativity, health and music programs.  The funds are allocated to:


1.  10% - Garden Oaks Creativity Festival, a festival to inspire the students to find their passion and engage in art & creativity programs
2. 40% - Create art, health & creativity programs at Garden Oaks Magnet Montessori
3. 40% - #MADenergy Launch Party & Fundraiser for Garden Oaks Magnet Montessori 
4.  5% - Supplies
5.  5% - Marketing & PR of the events and programs



The impact your donation has on the students of Garden Oaks is tremendous. Kids require creative outlets! Imagine what school would have been like without any art or music classes? No band? No painting, drawing, coloring?  No place for creative expression!  Removing these creativity programs from the school experience affects students' involvement and ability to truly learn.  In the past, most of the elementary school education revolved around some sort of artistic activity. The Garden Oaks School has little to no district funding for these areas of education.   Every aspect of their arts programs are currently being generously donated by parents, teachers, volunteers and the community.  Please support us in making a longterm difference in their lives. Have a hand in shaping their futures! You will also be giving a helping hand to MadRat Bevco, a company that believes success is directly attributed to the health and prosperity of their customers and community! 



“And the day came when the risk to remain tight in a bud was more painful than the risk it took to blossom.”― Anaïs Nin
“A ship is safe in harbor, but that's not what ships are for.”― William G.T. Shedd
“Only those who will risk going too far can possibly find out how far one can go.”― T.S. Eliot
“Life is either a daring adventure or nothing at all.”― Helen Keller
“Risks must be taken because the greatest hazard in life is to risk nothing.”― Leo Buscaglia
“Do not stop thinking of life as an adventure. You have no security unless you can live bravely, excitingly, imaginatively; unless you can choose a challenge instead of competence.”― Eleanor Roosevelt
  


Honestly, you don't need money to still be a valuable asset to our campaign.  When you become aware of our cause, please forward the message to your friends and family. Simply spreading the word is just as important as the donations themselves! The Indiegogo staff thought about this, and kindly provided us all with tools throughout the site to share this wonderful content.  Also, if you live in the Houston area and would like to donate art supplies or your time to teach art, music, creativity, health, wellness, etc.., we are honored to facilitate your involvement.
 

We are so blessed to have an energetic, inspired team of compassionate individuals who believe in the power of creativity!  We have a shared vision and belief in dreaming BIG!  We also have a lot of FUN!


The Casey Family - Founders of MadRat BevcoPayten, Kristal, Zayne & Dwayne 


Alisha Cunningham - Garden Oaks Liaison, Mother of 2 Garden Oaks Students, #MADfan & The Glue That Binds Us Together :)

Claudia De Velaso - Founder of Day To Remember, #HHFGH UH-Mazing Event Planner & Director of MADfun!
Bianca Bucaram - Co-Founder of Zapatero + Bucaram Public Relations, #HHFGH Spectacular Publicist & Genius Promoter with #MADheart <3




Austin Potts - Our "Right Hand Man", Cheerleader, Promoter & Lover of all things #MadRat
Trevor Gazaway - #MADsupporter & Promo Team-member
Alex Kaplan - #Elixr Enthusiast & Promo Team-member




MadRat Bevco is a holistic, healthy beverage company founded by Dwayne & Kristal Casey. Together, they created the first truly holistic energy drink, Elixr, made & manufactured deep in the heart of Texas!  Elixr supports MadRat Bevco’s goal - create healthy beverages that increase energy, inspire creativity and encourage bliss. Their passion to spread health, creativity and happiness is a driving force in their business!
These pioneers of healthy energy have set their sights on contributing to the community, by partnering with the Garden Oaks Magnet Montessori, an HISD school, to help raise money for their creativity and health programs.The MadRat Bevco team believes wholeheartedly that their own success is dependent on a prosperous and energetic world. They desire you to join them in bettering the world together! Through great energy, health and happiness!
We desire to extend our heartfelt thanks and #MADgratitude to our family, friends, supporters, fans & customers.  Your belief in us has given us the energy to pursue our dreams.  We are grateful beyond words and honored to have you all in our lives. Special thanks to:Dr. Lindsey Pollock, Principal, Garden Oaks Magnet MontessoriAlisha Cunningham, PTO Liaison, Garden Oaks Magnet Montessori
Barbie Atkinson, PTO President, Garden Oaks Magnet MontessoriToni Valle, PTO Arts & Enrichment Chair, Garden Oaks Magnet MontessoriSteve & Karen Cline, Karen Cline RealtorsPreston Kiser, CHIEFDOODLE ProductionsBianca Bucaram & Jessica Zapatero, Zapatero + Bucaram Public Relations Claudia De Velasco, A Day To Remember Event Planning
Robert Thompson
Anita ScanlanAnd countless others who have loved and supported us!  May God bless you all beyond your wildest dreams!!

story:
Hi,


My name is Ira. I am a Freelance Artist. I've been doing graphic / design / character art work for about 2 and a half years now. I will try my best to keep this short, simple and sweet-ish. So here it goes...

My goal is to purchase printer ink:

 Canon Ink Set

My funding goal is actually the amount of the ink (which is about $75 with tax). I decided to see if I can earn it by doing personalized art / characters / designs for anyone who would be interested in having art done. I've worked on games, logos, children's books, cartoon portraits, etc. Whatever idea you have in mind, I can most likely bring it to life.

Here are some examples of my artwork:


Now a days, I mainly work in vector format with bold lines, but I am not limited to it. Please visit my online portfolio to see more of my work:

Online Portfolio


***Custom Art Prize Listing***

$5 - Simple, black & white, sketch portrait or simple item

$15 - Half body, black & and white, inked character or medium complex item

$25 - Full body, flat colors, inked character or complex item ( This will come with a small print option if funding goal is reached!)

$50 - Full illustration, colored, inked, the works/ complex items (This will come with a large print option if funding goal is reached!)


Just let me know what fun things you would like drawn for you, for someone, for a business, etc. and I shall bring it to life! Please note, the art will be yours (full copyright ownership). You can use it as you see fit. Ultimately, I am grateful for any amount.  Printer ink is pretty expensive (arg). If I get enough funding,  those who donate $25 and up will also get a printed version of the art work =)

Well, that's about it. Thank you for taking the time to check out my little campaign!

Cheers*
-Ira

story:
Short Summary

Thank you for checking out our project, The Big Sexy. This is a book of pin-ups and nude artworks inspired by the women of the real world. The intent of this book is to offer a different perspective of the female form that is sorely lacking in modern pop art forms, speaking particularly to pop-art in the United States. The objective is simple and clear: let's show women, who are indeed beautiful, in every shape, form and shade that actually exists in our world. 

One thing that makes this unique compared to another pin-up book is that it will be, in part, participant generated. Meaning, certain pledge levels have been created so that the unique perspective of this book will be generated by a woman's perspective instead of merely being my own thoughts on the subject.

story:
Short Summary

 Hello world, my name is Gary Suraci and I am the founder of Artists for Autism.  My two major passions in life are working with kids with special needs and creating art in various forms, ( i.e. painting, sketch, charcoal, and photography). I have a Masters in Public Administration fro m Marist College, with a concentration in nonprofit administration.  I spent six amazing months at the University of Rome studying fine art and art history.  I have worked and volunteered with children with special needs for over five years now. Two of those years have been at PNW BOCES in Westchester.  More specifically I have experience working with children who have Autism, Traumatic Brain Injury, Cerebral Palsy, Down Syndrome, and Aspersers.  Each child I have worked with has changed my life and motivates me everyday to be a better person. 

This campaign is very important to me because it’s combining my two passions in life are art and working with children with special needs! I have the opportunity to create art and sell that art while taking a portion of the proceeds and donating them to special education schools in order to help these inspirational children.  I am so excited and very fortunate to be able to start this company and help make a difference in a child's life who truly deserves it.   

Each contribution that is received will make a significant difference and will help out these children in so many ways. These funds are needed to help build a strong, safe, and efficient, website for anyone at anytime, anywhere to purchase an aesthetic masterpiece while consciously knowing they are helping a child with disabilities. Even a dollar can go so far in this campaign and each dollar is a dollar close to making this company one that makes a lasting impact for a child with special needs. Please help me help these children and provide a service with a purpose. 

What We Need & What You Get

In order to make this a successful campaign I am going to need to raise at least $5,000.  Although this may seem to be a lot of money at first it really is not.  Every dollar that is raised through this campaign even if  it does not reach the full goal will be used for two important things.  Most of the money will go towards creating a company website.  This website is going to be extremely efficient, effective, easy to navigate, and safe for anyone to use.  The website is going to be one of the main tools for Artists for Autism.  The main function of the website is to provide an online place where donators can view the artist who is involved in the project and their works.  Once the donator finds an artist or a personalized piece that they like they then can place an order to purchase that piece or request a particular piece.  Besides being a portal to purchase art, the other purpose of the website will be to inform the donators where there money goes and how it directly made a difference in a child’s life with disabilities.  

The great news is that each donation you will receive a PERK ! Depending on the donation amount you can receive anything from a custom black and white photo, a personal painting, even a DVD of the artists artwork and a custom art kit which includes an instructional video.  

 The Impact

Everyday more children are being born with disabilities both physical and mental.  These amazing kids deserve any help they can get in anyway.  Please know that our main purpose is to raise money through our artwork in order to help these kids by donating money to their schools and purchasing adaptive equipment and technology needed for them to better access their academic environment. 

Other Ways You Can Help

I understand that these are tough economic times and its hard to spare with ones hard earned money.  If you cannot donate you can still help and make a difference.  So all I ask of you is to please spread the word!! Please let friends, family members, and coworkers know about Artists for Autism and our mission to help developmentally disabled special needs.  This is just as important as a monetary donation. 

Another great way to spread the word about AFA is to use the Indiegogo share tools! Its easy, quick, and helps get the word out quick. 

And that’s all there is to it.

Thank you for your time, consideration, and more importantly support and donations.

Artists For Autism
