story:
Our Story

 

Fowler Arts Collective is a studio and gallery collective located in the historic Greenpoint Terminal Market building on the Brooklyn waterfront. Established in July of 2010 by Lia Post, Fowler's Founder, Director and only employee, Fowler offers visual artists affordable studio spaces and access to communal facilities such as a small woodshop, an artists' lounge, and a gallery space. There are 18 studios in Fowler housing 24 artists working in painting, sculpture, photography, and illustration. We also have a 900 square foot gallery and event space which is the site for collaborative visual art exhibitions, classes, events, and readings. We curate one to two month shows of talented emerging artists and also accept exhibition and event proposals from New York City artists and beyond.


Fowler is seeking funding to help support and expand our gallery and events program with a dedicated budget as well as to ensure that our artist studio spaces remain as affordable as possible as rent for the space inevitably rises. Our home is a raw (but beautiful) warehouse space with a very basic heating system. Last winter was so cold we had to wear gloves while we worked in our studios! A large part of the funding we are seeking will go towards installing a duct system to distribute heat throughout our space more efficiently. Read below for a detailed break-down of the upgrades we would like to add to our space if we reach our funding goal.


Fowler is based on the idea that art is fundamentally a way to communicate with others using a visual language and that working within a lively community of other artists can be a huge benefit artistically, energetically, and even financially. The community at Fowler has been building and growing, and we want the chance to keep doing so! We have received wonderfully positive press during these past 8 months. Check out our press links here. Also, check out a video by James Kalm, of the Brooklyn Rail, to tour one of our recent exhibitions, FIST CITY. Note the uniquely gritty alleyway that leads you into the Fowler space.


Fowler is fiscally sponsored by Fractured Atlas, a non-profit arts organization, so any donation you make is tax deductible. Each level of donation receives a special gift from Fowler. As a benefit for the different levels of giving we have stickers, mugs, T-shirts, tote bags, artwork by Fowler artists, and more! 

 

The Impact

 

Affordable studio space in New York City is extremely difficult to find. The fact that the studios at Fowler are always filled to capacity is a testament to the fact that Fowler came to the right neighborhood at the right time! Fowler is making it work with very little funds, but we are in desperate need of some basic facilities upgrades and a dedicated budget for the gallery and events program. Receiving this funding would ensure that Fowler has the opportunity to continue being a part of the artistic community of New York and that its small family of artists can continue to thrive. 


As a collective, Fowler is not a traditional gallery. We function as a non-profit, and the gallery program is focused on exhibiting collaborative exhibitions between artists. By focusing on collaborative exhibitions, Fowler gives the selected artists a chance to take over the gallery and produce a show that they otherwise would not have the opportunity to organize, free of space or financial restrictions. The Fowler studios are based directly on graduate art school studio buildings with open studio plans, shared communal facilities, and hang-out areas (check out a slide show of our artists spaces here). The gallery and studio areas are not separated, so any event or exhibition in the gallery brings visitors and dialogue into the Fowler artist's studios. Fowler started out as a vast, empty industrial space. It has since evolved into a hotbed of artistic pursuit. Check out a slide show of the space being constructed by Lia and a few Fowler artists last summer. We have come a long way!  


The Greenpoint neighborhood of Brooklyn is filled with artists of all kinds, but it lacks a cohesive gallery and arts scene. Fowler aims to be a site for this community of artists to meet, collaborate, and learn. Since our very first opening exhibition in October 2010, Fowler has become an important part of the emerging artist community in North Brooklyn. Check out a slide show of our October 1st, 2010 opening here. Since then, we have produced five successful exhibitions, and we have stayed afloat -- with flair! -- despite a very small budget. For more information on and photos of the five exhibitions we produced this year, check out the pages dedicated to each one by clicking these titles: ENTER, soft bigotry for a mercy killing, Keep The Home Fires Burning, FIST CITY, and Paint It Now. 

 

What We Need & What You Get

 

Fowler is seeking funding to help support and expand the gallery and events program with a dedicated budget as well as to ensure that the studio spaces remain as affordable as possible as rent for the space inevitably rises. We are also in need of some basic upgrades to our space: a better heating system, drinking water, and a bigger fridge. Such basic needs, but so necessary for the continued health of this collective. We have an exciting array of perks available for any level of contribution. Most of our perks are made in the Fowler studios by our own hands. Check out our perks to the right ... every contribution will help us know we have a community of love and support behind us!


Our Fundraising Goals


Facilities Wish-List


Adding ductwork to the heater in the space so we don’t freeze again this winter brrrrrr: $800-$1000


(Set of lockers to keep valuables safe: $800)

**UPDATE: We were just gifted a set of lockers from the building we live in-- so nice! So instead of lockers: 


Poland Springs drinking water for a year. There is no drinking water in our building, so having a water cooler would improve the Fowler quality of life and save the world from those plastic water bottles we've been buying: $400


Bigger fridge. We have a mini-fridge that is much too mini for 25 artists. We can upgrade from mini-fridge to half-fridge: $400

 

Any money we don't use for these expenses, or if we happen to make more than our goal (yay?!), will be used to protect the artists from rent increases as our lease renews every year.


Gallery Wish-List

 

Upgraded Lighting: 7 fixtures at about $60 each plus 18 halogen light bulbs: $800


Exhibition budget for the next 6 to 8 months: $3000 

(budget covers catalog printing, hanging hardware, paint for the walls, trash pick-up after openings, beer and wine, and many misc. supplies particular to each exhibition).

 

Total Funds to be Raised: $6,000


Other Ways You Can Help

 

If you have visited Fowler and fallen in love, or you just admire Fowler’s optimism and drive, please share our campaign on Facebook and Twitter and let all your friends and family know about us! Please use the "share" options linked on this page directly under our video. Any trackback to our campaign using these links helps us even more! 


Every single donation, no matter how small, will make a huge difference to the life of this artist collective. We are artists—we can make so much with very little! Please make a donation today! And come to visit us. We would love to meet you. Find us through our website.

 

For more information and photographs, please visit these websites. Love, Fowler

 

Website: http://www.fowlerartsbrooklyn.org

 

Blog: http://fowlerartsbrooklyn.tumblr.com/

 

Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/fowlerartscollective


Twitter: https://twitter.com/#!/fowlerarts
story_txt:
Our Story
 
Fowler Arts Collective is a studio and gallery collective located in the
historic Greenpoint Terminal Market building on the Brooklyn waterfront. Established in July of 2010 by Lia Post, Fowler's Founder, Director and only
employee, Fowler offers visual artists affordable studio spaces and access to
communal facilities such as a small woodshop, an artists' lounge, and a
gallery space. There are 18 studios in Fowler housing 24 artists working in painting, sculpture, photography, and illustration. We also have a 900 square foot gallery and event space which is the site for collaborative visual art exhibitions, classes, events, and readings. We curate one to two month shows of talented emerging artists and also accept exhibition and event proposals from New York City artists and beyond.Fowler is seeking funding to help support and expand our gallery and events program with a dedicated budget as well as to ensure that our artist studio spaces remain as affordable as possible as rent for the space inevitably rises. Our home is a raw (but beautiful) warehouse space with a very basic heating system. Last winter was so cold we had to wear gloves while we worked in our studios! A large part of the funding we are seeking will go towards installing a duct system to distribute heat throughout our space more efficiently. Read below for a detailed break-down of the upgrades we would like to add to our space if we reach our funding goal.Fowler is based on the idea that art is fundamentally a way to 
communicate with others using a visual language and that working within a
 lively community of other artists can be a huge benefit artistically, 
energetically, and even financially. The community at Fowler has been 
building and growing, and we want the chance to keep doing so! We have 
received wonderfully positive press during these past 8 months. Check 
out our press links here. Also, check out a video by James Kalm, of the Brooklyn Rail, to tour one of our recent exhibitions, FIST CITY. Note the uniquely gritty alleyway that leads you into the Fowler space.Fowler is fiscally sponsored by Fractured Atlas, a non-profit arts organization, so any donation you make is tax deductible. Each level of donation receives a special gift from Fowler. As a benefit for the different levels of giving we have stickers, mugs, T-shirts, tote bags, artwork by Fowler artists, and more!  
The Impact
 
Affordable studio space in New York City is extremely difficult to find. The fact that the studios at Fowler are always filled to capacity is a testament to the fact that Fowler came to the right neighborhood at the right time! Fowler is making it work with very little funds, but we are in desperate need of some basic facilities upgrades and a dedicated budget for the gallery and events program. Receiving this funding would ensure that Fowler has the opportunity to continue being a part of the artistic community of New York and that its small family of artists can continue to thrive. As a collective, Fowler is not a traditional gallery. We function as a 
non-profit, and the gallery program is focused on exhibiting collaborative exhibitions between
 artists. By focusing on collaborative exhibitions, Fowler gives the 
selected artists a chance to take over the gallery and produce a show 
that they otherwise would not have the opportunity to organize, free of 
space or financial restrictions. The Fowler studios are based directly 
on graduate art school studio buildings with open studio plans, shared 
communal facilities, and hang-out areas (check out a slide show of our 
artists spaces here).
 The gallery and studio areas are not separated, so any event or 
exhibition in the gallery brings visitors and dialogue into the Fowler 
artist's studios. Fowler started out as a vast, empty industrial space. 
It has since evolved into a hotbed of artistic pursuit. Check out a slide show of the space being constructed by Lia and a few Fowler artists last summer. We have come a long way!   The Greenpoint neighborhood of Brooklyn is filled with
artists of all kinds, but it lacks a cohesive gallery and arts scene. Fowler
aims to be a site for this community of artists to meet, collaborate, and
learn. Since our very first opening exhibition in October 2010, Fowler has become
an important part of the emerging artist community in North Brooklyn. Check out a slide show of our October 1st, 2010 opening here. Since then, we have
produced five successful exhibitions, and we have stayed afloat -- with flair! --
despite a very small budget. For more information on and photos of the five exhibitions we produced this year, check out the pages dedicated to each one by clicking these titles: ENTER, soft bigotry for a mercy killing, Keep The Home Fires Burning, FIST CITY, and Paint It Now.   
What We Need & What You Get
 
Fowler is seeking funding to help support and expand the
gallery and events program with a dedicated budget as well as to ensure that the
studio spaces remain as affordable as possible as rent for the space
inevitably rises. We are also in need of some basic upgrades to our space: a better heating system, drinking water, and a bigger fridge. Such basic needs, but so necessary for the continued health of this collective. We have an exciting array of perks available for any level of contribution. Most of our perks are made in the Fowler studios by our own hands. Check out our perks to the right ... every contribution will help us know we have a community of love and support behind us!
Our Fundraising Goals

Facilities Wish-List
Adding ductwork to the heater in the space so we don’t
freeze again this winter brrrrrr: $800-$1000
(Set of lockers to keep valuables safe: $800) **UPDATE: We were just gifted a set of lockers from the building we live in-- so nice! So instead of lockers: Poland Springs drinking water for a year. There is no drinking water in our building, so having a water cooler would improve the Fowler quality of life and save the world from those plastic water bottles we've been buying: $400Bigger fridge. We have a mini-fridge that is much too mini for 25 artists. We can upgrade from mini-fridge to half-fridge: $400
 
Any money we don't use for these expenses, or if we happen to make more than our goal (yay?!), will be used to protect the artists from rent increases as our lease renews every year.Gallery Wish-List Upgraded Lighting: 7 fixtures at about $60 each plus 18 halogen light bulbs: $800Exhibition budget for the next 6 to 8 months: $3000 (budget covers catalog printing, hanging hardware, paint for the walls, trash pick-up after openings, beer and wine, and many misc. supplies particular to each exhibition). 
Total Funds to be Raised: $6,000
Other Ways You Can Help
 
If you have visited Fowler and fallen in love, or you just admire
Fowler’s optimism and drive, please share our campaign on Facebook and Twitter and let
all your friends and family know about us! Please use the "share" options linked on this page directly under our video. Any trackback to our campaign using these links helps us even more! Every single donation, no matter how small, will
make a huge difference to the life of this artist collective. We are artists—we
can make so much with very little! Please make a donation today! And come to visit us. We would love
to meet you. Find us through our website.
 
For more information and photographs, please visit these websites. Love, Fowler
 
Website: http://www.fowlerartsbrooklyn.org
 
Blog: http://fowlerartsbrooklyn.tumblr.com/
 
Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/fowlerartscollectiveTwitter: https://twitter.com/#!/fowlerarts

story:
Dino & Panda T-shirts

Hi hi :)

My name is Elaine~

My goal for this campaign is $1000 and I would like to create 100 hand-painted T-shirts (not silk screened...every tshirt will be unique!) I plan to reserve 50 of the T-shirts for sale at local art shows in my hometown, and the rest will be available for purchase from fans all over the world!

Let me tell you a bit about myself so you know I'm not a weird psycho.

I'm a 4th year university student (Visual Arts Major) and I plan to do more school to eventually become an elementary school teacher :) That means...I will continue being poor for a little while longer... HOWEVER! Nothing can keep me away from making art! I spend most of my time outside of school volunteering with arts & crafts events where I can work with children, adults, and seniors.  Feelings of happiness from all these opportunities fuel a lot of my own artwork -a constant source of inspiration.

My awesome fans on Facebook have continually given me encouragement to get t-shirts printed featuring my Dino & Panda and all their friends for quite some time now, but I'm a starving university student and I didn't know where to start!

Recently, we had a lovely guest speaker in one of my classes who introduced us to the concept of crowdfunding.  Needless to say, I was super excited to try it out :)

For those who don't know much about Dino & Panda, you can visit my facebook fanpage: http://www.facebook.com/Dino.Panda.Inc after you take a look at my campaign video to learn more :)  

If you have any questions please ask me! I'd love to tell you all about Dino & Panda :)

If Dino & Panda have brought a smile to your face, I hope you can spread that love and joy to someone close to you too!  Spreading happiness is what we do best (by "we" I mean Dino & Panda, and I. hehe)!

Thanks a million for watching :D

Dino & Panda's Thank-you gifts:

I realize $1000 may not cover all the costs but I'm hoping it will at least cover most of the costs for tshirts, fabric paint, shipping, and other materials for the production of the perks I want to give to my contributors! 

Take a look at the various perks associated with each pledge level.  Some of the gifts include a cute pompom Panda, greeting cards, original drawings, and paintings. Dino & Panda would love to become a part of your lives :D

 

What's Next if this campaign is successful?

This is hopefully just the beginning of something more awesome.  I would love to be able to continue creating Dino & Panda t-shirts, tote bags, pillow cases, diaries....you name it! Everything! As long as Dino & Panda have the ability to cheer someone up, I want to work hard and spread their love everywhere :) 

I have a secret dream to start my own business someday and have Dino & Panda touch as many hearts as I can.  This campaign is a good way for me to test the waters and see how many people are interested in Dino & Panda merchandise.  I've been happy and content just sharing all my artwork on my fanpage till now but I guess I need to think about the reality of my situation as a jobless university student...

Plus, I want to fulfill the wishes of my fans :) I love you all! If this campaign isn't as successful as I hope it to be, please be a bit patient and wait until I can save up enough money to make this all possible! 

 

If you can't contribute, that's ok!

Don't feel bad if you aren't in a position to contribute to my $1000 goal. 
I know I'm not the only starving university student out there! Just become a fan of Dino & Panda and follow us on our journey, share with all your friends, and smile for us! 

Your smiles give me power. With power comes inspiration for more artwork! More artwork means more smiles...and more power! It's a positive feedback loop hehe~

Please let all your friends and family know about this campaign by using the Indiegogo share tools~ share on Facebook, Twitter, blogs, etc. 

Dino & Panda love getting comments on their drawings so if you're a fan on facebook don't be shy! Leave a message! I always do my best to reply every message. All of them. 

Alright, I could speak forever about Dino & Panda and how much I love my fans, but I feel like I've written a book...Do you feel like you've just read a novel?! If you had the patience to read my life story, I thank you! haha I hope Dino & Panda have touched your hearts now that you've seen the campaign video. 

 

PS. I'm sorry I use so many smileys when I type.  I'm just really happy when I think about people smiling because of my Dino & Panda artwork. :D

story:
Who am I & What is Masala Collage?

My name is Antonio Merinero I am a graphic artist and travelling is the thread in my life and work. Extensive travels through my native Spain, Europe, Latin America and Asia are a limitless source of inspiration for my artwork.

The route, search, outcome and interpretation differ worldwide, yet there are a few stations through which we all pass. Birth, death, spirituality, passion and the pain when love is gone are among those that make all of us so beautifully human. Although mankind lives in violent disagreement most of the time we all recognise these universals easily.

It was this all-encompassing yet simple idea that inspired me to compose a jigsaw of letters, postcards, my draws and paintings and those of others fellow artist met on the road, to cut and glue a journey of live and other stories.

Masala Collage is what I like to call human collage, composed by lots of people from different cultures and places. It goes up to small mountain villages and down into the cellars of the metropolis looking for artisans, sign makers and painters, representatives of the arts in danger of extinction. It creates lively, visual stories, in which the narrative force of each artisan, painter and letterer join before the paint dries up forever.

Masala Collage on Tour unites in words and images the apparently distinct, the universal.


What is Masala Collage?

Masala Collage is a handcrafted collage collection made by Spanish artist Antonio Merinero and many artist from several Asian countries. It is a travelling art investigation and collaboration with the varying cultural insights on life as a driving force. Because life’s a journey –destination unknown– from 2004 to the present, five editions of these collage were finished, adding around eighty pieces of art with formats ranging between 70x100 and 300x600 cm.

An ever continuous project. In 2007 masala collages became Masala collages On Tour and Not for Sale. It is and will be co-owned by everyone all over the planet who made its existence possible.

Masala Collage "On Tour" showcases my work and the work of other artists and crafters from remotes sites, it has worked as a platform for workshops where we worked together on a fullfilling experience that cross the boundaries of races, cultures or religions.


What is the plan?

This year the plan is to return to Thailand with Cervantes. Go to Thailand with translated abstracts and quotes from Cervantes Quixote and find craftsmen or artists who enjoy the idea of reflecting on the old Spanish master´s words from a Thai point of view and create collages together, visually capturing this powerful blend of cross cultural thought on life.
Masala Collage On Tour is part of a whole, the need now is to make a linking step between its previous edition in India "Life as a journey" (see blog for details) to Thailand's "The Madness of it All" to the following edition in Miami, U.S.A., where we are expected by the end of this year. Masala Thailand will be on show and Masala Miami will be born. A new edition with a new theme, leitmotif and more and more artists joining our ever growing modest yet great network to have more cross cultural fun, and share thoughts on life.


What do we need and where the money will go

I need 4000$. to pay for:

International transport return ticket Madrid-Bangkok.

Local transport train, bus.

International transport of finished pieces Bangkok - Madrid

Materials for the production of the pieces

Final mounting of the pieces.

Wages of local artists

Wooden box for artwork transportation

Plain and simple meals (vital to keep going).

Hotels whenever couchsourfing not available

etc,

Till now I have been financing this project out of my own pocket and with some small grants from institutions, that I contribute every now and then, after long months of paper work, calls, visits to official buildings and other time comsuming tasks. But because Masala's spirit is sharing, I thought that trying to find "crowdfunding" makes perfect sense.Whenever possible I will be couchsurfing to lower spending but really to find easier acces to Thai life and  to navigate the country with Thai help and company.


What you get

Masala Collage on Tour is not for sale but contributors can get little pieces that spill out of the project during the production. I will be displaying some in the Gallery.

For 10$ Contribution you get a Masala Collage postcard with OOAK alteration, written, signed and posted by Antonio Merinero from Thailand to you.
For 50$ Contribution you get a Full Masala Collage India postcard Collection (30 uni. in its folder) signed by Merinero on the Cover

For 100$ Contribution you get an original OOAK collage from the serial "love letters" made during this trip and send to you from Thailand, signed by Merinero and dedicated to you on the back.
For 200$ contribution you get a 30x40cm. photo by Merinero made during the trip,  signed (limited edition of 5)


For 300$ contribution you get an Original size A4 Collage, made during this trip and, send from Thailand and dedicated to you on the back. 
For 500$ contribution you get the full perk packett: the postcard, the postcard collection, the 10x20cm. collage, the photograph and the A4 collage.

For 800$ contribution you get your own private 70 cm. by 100 cm. masala thailand 2011 collage.


All contributors receive my eternal thankfullness, warm hugs and an invitation for the Opening Party of the Miami exhibition.

story:
Thank you for visiting No Music No Life art installation! It will be located in the Parks Dept Art Walk at Burning Flipside!

The funding raised here will go toward the rest of the material, cost of transportation, and a few extras I didn't originally budget for. My heart has been put into this project and it is turning out to cost more than I originall planned. Please help make my dream a reality. I cannot wait to bring my art to the community I have grown so much to love!

What is it?

A 3-demensional communication of music. Each letter to spell out M-U-S-I-C are made from collages on different music media. Letters will glow and send the message that music brings people together! 

 

M-U-S-I-C will be spelled out using 4ft tall plywood peices. Each letter will have a different music media piece M-cassette tapes, U-Records/45's, S-cd's, I-musical instruments, C-music lyrics. The music media will create collages to cover every part of plywood by gluing. 

Solar lights will surround the bottom of each post connected to the plywood. EL wire will be used to outline each line so it will glow at night and will be safe for people.

Battery opperated inverters will be used for EL wire power. They will blink, flash, and glow. Solar lights will look like blades of grass and change color.

 Some media like the records, cassettes, and cd's will have collages created on them by different community members from magazine cutouts. Each letter will have slightly different widths (because of the general shape of the letter) but will all be the same height (4ft). Wooden post 2x4's (6 of them) will be used to hold each plywood letter up. The M will use 2 of these. Each wooden post will be 7 ft long and will be submerged in the ground by 3 ft to hold the plywood up steadily.

 Thank you for taking the time to check this project out! I know it will turn out wonderfully because of you!

story:
In a flutter of brilliantly coloured drapery, two women move together in an embrace. Eyes locked, their intense gaze shows both joy and deep understanding; they are exchanging the happy news that they are both pregnant.

This is the Visitation, a masterpiece of Renaissance art by the enigmatic painter Pontormo. The meeting between cousins Mary and Elisabeth, and of their unborn children Jesus and John, are represented in a way that even now, five hundred years later, is innovative and captivatingly beautiful. The Visitation speaks a universal language of emotion, motherhood, hope and salvation. Her message at this time is to save her home.

[Pontormo's Visitation in Carmignano]

This painting resides in a small parish church in Carmignano, a town in Tuscany, about half an hour’s drive from Florence. Long a site of “pilgrimage” for art lovers, Pontormo’s Visitation has embarked on her first American tour with the exhibition “Miraculous Encounters: Pontormo from Drawing to Painting” (Florence - New York - Los Angeles). The purpose of the #VisitingVisitation, as we are calling the voyage of this gift to humanity, is to raise funds for the much-needed restoration of this church.

The church and monastic complex of San Michele Arcangelo that is home to Pontormo’s Visitation, one of the most important artworks of its time, is literally falling down. Emergency interventions have taken place to fix holes in the roof of the church when rainwater was entering close to the painting, but this is just the most visible and alarming sign of widespread structural damage to the large complex, which includes a cloister, oratory and additional internal spaces.

[The church interior with Pontormo's painting on the right]

We have a plan - described in detail below - to restore the heart of the complex - the house of the Visitation; preserve the painting for future generations of Carmignanesi; and give life to the Museum of the Visitation so that art-loving visitors from around the world can come admire this work in its home for years to come.

[One of the many sections of the convent in which it is unsafe to enter]

We are asking you to become a part of this project and help save this church and convent from ruin. Please contribute by donating any amount, either freely or by selecting one of the rewards at the right hand side of this page [see this post for rewards details].

The loan of Pontormo’s Visitation in order to be the starring masterpiece of the exhibition “Miraculous Encounters: Pontormo from Drawing to Painting” has permitted further study of the painting and deepened our understanding both of the artist, and of how this work came to be in our church in Carmignano. 

Bruce Edelstein, curator of the exhibit and Coordinator for Graduate Programs and Advanced Research at New York University Florence, presents a new hypothesis about the patronage and dating of the work. In short, the work was likely commissioned by Bonaccorso Pinadori and executed in the period 1528-30, in which Florence was under siege and the city was governed by a short-lived Republic before it was once again taken over by the Medici family, who would then consolidate their rule, becoming Dukes and then Grand Dukes of Tuscany for the following 200 years. 

[Carmignano from above, with the church at its center]

The painting was not made for the church in Carmignano, but, Edelstein suggests, was commissioned for a Franciscan church outside of the city walls which was destroyed during the siege. Thus, the owner, who was a Medici enemy, took it to the family villa in Carmignano, where they had a private chapel. It is documented here in 1677, and then next mentioned in our church in 1720. It may have been transferred there when, that same year, the Pinadori family sold the villa. It was made to fit an altar frame that was designed for another painting, perhaps once promised by the now financially unfortunate Pinadori family.

While Pontormo’s panel was not made for the church in Carmignano, it certainly found an ideal location in this Franciscan setting and became particularly important to this community. For more than two hundred years, it never left the church; afterwards, it has only traveled to Florence, for restoration and a handful of exhibitions. Travel has only ever been authorized for the good of the painting, in terms of scientific study, restoration, and now fundraising.

The Church of San Michele is said to have been founded on land donated to Saint Francis himself in 1211. An oratory and friary were built, and expanded with the current church in the first half of the fourteenth century. Another expansion took place in the eighteenth century.

[The exterior of the church]

In the modern period, lack of funds has led to the progressive degradation of the building, in particular in structural terms. The vertical pilasters that support the building require consolidation since they risk collapse, while the wooden structure of the roof has been attacked by parasites and affected by water damage. Continued rainwater exposure to all the parts of the complex, due to the inadequate roof, has affected structural aspects as well as damaged architectural and painted decoration. Temporary measures have been taken from 1994 until now to patch holes in the roof and to hold up walls and floors, rendering numerous areas inaccessible.

[From above you can see where the roof is caving in, and part of it is green plastic sheeting]

We remember times when the beautiful cloister held joyous celebrations of marriages and baptisms; when the complex provided a useful and free meeting space for youth groups and community activities. We want to get back to that, to once again have wedding parties in this space, and to welcome new visitors and types of festivities through a new museum.

[Our group of volunteers recently cleaned the cloister so we could hold fundraising concerts here! It hadn't been open to the public in almost two decades.]

Our hope is to be able to finance a full restoration of the complex, but we’ve structured our plan bit by bit, over the long term. The church will always be the fulcrum of community events, and it will also take on a new role as the Museum of the Visitation.

  • The first goal will be to secure the church and make sure that the painting, when it returns home from its American voyage, will be safe and dry. 
  • Second, we’re renovating an area on the ground floor adjacent to the church, to become an exhibition space, event space, and visitor welcome center.
  • An intervention on the Oratory of San Luca will permit it to be reopened to the public. With time, regular prayer services will be moved to this more intimate space, permitting tourist visits in the main church to not disturb prayer.

This rendering give an idea of what the future museum will look like once the restoration is complete. The intention is to create a space in which to prepare the visitor for viewing the painting by Pontormo in its original location inside the church. The Museo della Visitazione will also house reproductions, videos, and temporary exhibitions, as well as offer visitor services.

To restore the entire complex is a long term project requiring substantial funding. We are concentrating on the section that we wish to open up to the public in the short term. The amount required to do this work is €965,000 ($1.13M).

The amount we hope to raise through crowdfunding is a minimal amount that will permit us to start work right away, before other promised funding arrives. The Diocese of Pistoia is setting aside a large portion of the funds required for this restoration, but these will not arrive before the end of 2019. In the meantime, we need to consolidate the structure so that the already-bad situation does not worsen. Having these funds immediately will allow us to start work right away: the church and complex cannot wait another two years until promised funds are freed up.

For this reason we have opened a long term fundraising on our website (pontormo.it), of which this section on Indiegogo is part.

We have a large and qualified team able to carry out the projected works and museum, including:

  • Tommaso Londi, Architect: for the past decade, Dr. Londi has been monitoring and intervening on the complex where necessity and funds permitted. He has developed the full plans for the restoration and identified a qualified construction team to undertake it as soon as funds are available.
  • Fabrizio Buricchi (Responsabile dei Beni Culturali, Chiesa di San Michele) and Lawyer Barbara Londi, Fundraising: working as a team and as part of the commission of parishioners actively seeking to save the church, Barbara and Fabrizio have secured funds from private and public sources.
  • Bruce Edelstein, curator and scholar: Curator of the traveling exhibit, Bruce’s scientific research is an invaluable contribution to the diffusion of information about our painting and the church complex, which will be also used in the future museum design and contents.
  • Don Elia, parish priest, and Don Cristiano, vicario episcopale.
  • Flod, crowdfunding consultation (Alexandra Korey, Marco Badiani, Giovanni Giusti and Vincenzo D'Angelo): this Florence-based communications agency has previously raised funds for the restoration of important artworks such as #TheFirstLast.
  • A team of local volunteers: numerous residents of Carmignano and beyond have answered a call to contribute to this campaign in various ways. Videographers, storytellers, event organizers and simply people who can pass on the news are all playing their part.
  • Video by Tommaso Santi who just won best screenplay for a short film at the Venice Film Festival!

Thanks to the traveling exhibition "Miraculous Encounters: Pontormo from Drawing to Painting," word about the need for a good home for Pontormo's masterpiece is getting out. Please mark your calendar to see the show in one of these locations, or pick a special guided tour as your reward on this platform for a truly special experience that will also help support us.

  • New York (NY), USA: The Morgan Library & Museum, September 7 2018 to January 6, 2019
  • Los Angeles (CA), USA: The J. Paul Getty Museum, February 5 to April 28, 2019
  • Carmignano (PO), Italy: The painting will return (without the rest of the exhibition) to the Church of San Michele, after May 2019

Please choose from the perks on the right side of this page or make an open donation to support this campaign.

See this post for rewards details. Remember that you can give an amount that is greater than the amount requested for a perk if you would like that one in particular!

For donations by check, bank transfer, or special requests, please write to museodellavisitazione@gmail.com.

Media Partner

Technical Partner

Prize Sponsors

In a flutter of brilliantly coloured drapery, two women move together in an embrace. Eyes locked, their intense gaze shows both joy and deep understanding; they are exchanging the happy news that they are both pregnant.This is the Visitation, a masterpiece of Renaissance art by the enigmatic painter Pontormo. The meeting between cousins Mary and Elisabeth, and of their unborn children Jesus and John, are represented in a way that even now, five hundred years later, is innovative and captivatingly beautiful. The Visitation speaks a universal language of emotion, motherhood, hope and salvation. Her message at this time is to save her home.[Pontormo's Visitation in Carmignano]This painting resides in a small parish church in Carmignano, a town in Tuscany, about half an hour’s drive from Florence. Long a site of “pilgrimage” for art lovers, Pontormo’s Visitation has embarked on her first American tour with the exhibition “Miraculous Encounters: Pontormo from Drawing to Painting” (Florence - New York - Los Angeles). story:
Summary

Hello! My name is Brandon Stewart and I am an artist from Seattle, Washington. For over 10 years I have made my living as a freelance illustrator, pyrographer (woodburning) and tattoo artist. 

A few years ago, I came to Indiegogo looking for help to get to Spectrum Fantastic Art Live, a collection of some of the finest sci-fi/fantasy artists in the world. I had been accepted to exhibit at this event, and you all came through and helped me achieve my goal. And what an experience it was! I couldn't have thanked you all enough.

Well, I'm happy to say, I've been accepted again this year, and I am hoping your generosity will lead me back to this incredible opportunity.

What We Need

I am hoping to get together $2000 for this venture. Since there are too many variables when it comes to a near 4000 mile round trip drive, I'll break down my monetary needs the best that I can.

  • Fuel

For this drive, I figure I'll need roughly $500 for gas. Maybe more or less depending on fuel costs throughout the different states.

  • Lodging

I will be leaving Washington on Wednesday, April 19th and be returning Wednesday, April 26th. So, on average a cheaper motel is gonna run about $60-120 per night, and I'll be staying 7 nights in various places along my route. That's a variable rate of $420-840 in motel bills. I'm not trying to stay in fancy places, just ones without bugs.

  • Supplies

Supplies for this trip will include everything from art prints to food. While I have most of the materials necessary to do this show (things like a table, table cloth, bins...etc), there are some things I need to update:

  • I absolutely need a new banner for my booth. 
  • I want to step up my prints and get some fancier ones made of my art
  • I am happy with how I set up my table, but I would like to get some displays that allow me to show more stuff because I have expanded what I do since my last time at Spectrum. 
  • New business cards (already designed).

What You Get

  • Undying gratitude.

I can't begin to express what even the simplest of gestures means. Even if it's just a share on Facebook. Thank you!

  • A handwritten postcard from the road

I'll be writing and sending out hand-written postcards from various points in my venture. This perk begins at the $5 level and is in all above levels as well.

  • Prints

You'll get a choice of a print of varying size depending on your pledge level. Prints start at the $12 level and go up to $35. All are printed on archival art paper with archival inks. All are hand-signed by me as well.

  • Original artwork

All original artwork perks are handmade by me in various mediums. Details and sizes are in the perk description.

  • Tattoo work

Starting at the $50 level and going up to $500, you'll get a gift certificate with your name on it for tattoo work from me. Most of you donating to these perks will likely have already been tattooed by me, so you'll know the drill. Think of this as a deposit for your new tattoo or a continuation of something we have already started.

If you haven't already been tattooed by me and are considering a pledge to these perks, you can see some of my work here. 

The Impact

My last trip to Spectrum was surreal. Meeting artists I've admired for years, picking the brains of absolute giants in the industry, I walked away from that trip with a renewed sense of direction artistically; I came home armed with more inspiration than I knew what to do with. 

And I can only imagine this year will be the same. I cannot wait!

Risks & Challenges

Since I have done this before, I have the utmost confidence that I'll make it work again. 

Right now, I have most, if not all, of the rewards set aside and ready to go, so fulfilling those obligations won't be an issue. And I believe in most cases, that I'll be able to fulfill those perks sooner than I have listed.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't donate to the cause, it's ok, but please, SHARE this campaign with EVERYONE you know on Facebook, Twitter or whatever social media suits your fancy. Help this go as viral as all of those cute kitty videos!!!

story:
WHAT IS A GHOSTKUBE?

A GHOSTKUBE is a sculpture inspired by moving origami. It consists of cubes connected in a three-dimensional structure. You can manipulate it to change shapes in different ways. It is made from a system of pieces that lock together. When you want to try another design, you simply take it apart and build a different one using the exact same pieces. No matter if you are developing probes for you next Mars mission, constructing skyscrapers, or looking at atomic structures for nano technology, GHOSTKUBES can serve as an inspiration and a tool for creativity. What you see in the film is NOT a 3D printed prototype, it is a finished product from an industrial mold. I wanted to be 100% sure that I could offer a product that worked exactly as I intended. Building and disassembly instructions will be published online.

 

PLEDGE REWARDS IN PICTURES

The GHOSTKUBE comes in Cream White. The KEYSTONE, which is a loose single cube, comes in Moon Gray. Both have a matte finish.

 

Small Box

This box can build GHOSTKUBES which consist of up to 12 single cubes. Here are examples of what you can build with the pieces in the small box:

Big Box

The big box makes it possible to build any two GHOSTKUBES possible from the small box. It can build GHOSTKUBES which consist of up to 24 single cubes. Here are some examples of what you can build with the pieces in the big box:

Keystone

A KEYSTONE is a loose, single cube that you can use to lock a GHOSTKUBE into one position so it will no longer be able to change shape. This is great for display purposes or for adding stability to larger structures. It comes in Moon Gray.

Friend Set

The Friend Set is perfect if you have a friend you want to give a GHOSTKUBE to and you also want to have one for yourself. Or you could just be extra enthusiastic and want to have more options for your own constructions.

This set can build GHOSTKUBES, which consist of up to 48 single cubes.

The Friend Set contains: 2x GHOSTKUBE big box + 4x KEYSTONE

Architect Set

If you want to have several completed GHOSTKUBE designs at the same time, combine them into towers, or build really complex configurations, this is the reward for you.

This set can build GHOSTKUBES, which consist of up to 96 single cubes.

The Architect Set contains: 4x GHOSTKUBE big box + 6x KEYSTONE

 Master Builder Set

Maximize the possibilities with this set! I have invented hundreds of variations and will be releasing instructional videos so you will be able to really explore the possibilities of shape changing 3D space and structures.

This set can build GHOSTKUBES, which consist of up to 144 single cubes.

The Master Builder Set contains: 6x GHOSTKUBE big box + 10x KEYSTONE

 

HOW OLD SHOULD YOU BE / HOW HARD IS IT TO BUILD / HOW FRAGILE IS IT?

See it as a plastic model airplane in terms of difficulty and fragility. It is actually not as fragile or as difficult as that, but if that is what you expect, you will be fine. I do not want to make false claims in relation to the expectations for the product or disappoint anyone because they cannot build it. A child might need the assistance of an adult, but could eventually learn to build it without help in a reasonable amount of time. I would probably say that somewhere around 10-12 years old is the minimum age where a child could construct these. The instructions will be in video format, with English as the spoken language. Additional languages or subtitles may be added one day but until then, look at the film to understand what I am doing and follow along to complete your build!

TIMELINE

  • 2010 GHOSTKUBE idea
  • 2011 Equipped studio with needed tools
  • 2012 First GHOSTKUBE made in wood
  • 2013 Spent the whole year making them
  • 2014 Viral video on YouTube
  • 2015 Started working on plastic system 
  • 2016 Finding engineers and manufacturers
  • 2017 Prototyping the plastic system
  • 2018 Aug. finished mold
  • 2018 Dec. KICKSTARTER launch
  • 2019 Feb. Indiegogo launch
  • 2019 Feb. design packaging
  • 2019 March make instructional videos
  • 2019 April start manufacturing
  • 2019 June assembly of products
  • 2019 July product delivery starts (six months from the completion of the campaign). 

 

DELIVERY

We estimate that delivery will start in July 2019. 

Many backers will be wanting to give a GHOSTKUBE as a present to their friends or family for the holidays. I know that GHOSTKUBE will make a great gift for Christmas, Hanukkah, or whichever holiday(s) you may celebrate, therefore I have made a printable gift certificate that you can give to your friends to let them know that a GHOSTKUBE is coming their way!

CLICK HERE TO DOWNLOAD A PRINTABLE PDF

MANUFACTURING

The GHOSTKUBE is designed and manufactured in Sweden. It has been patented.

 

SPREAD THE WORD

Are you a blogger, a journalist, or just an enthusiast who want to help out?

Here is a link to an open Google Drive with exclusive, high quality pictures, and some complementary information about the project for you to use as needed. Feel free to share it as you like! Click this link:

PRESS KIT GOOGLE DRIVE 

 

WANT TO SEE MORE?

  • Instagram:  https://www.instagram.com/erik_aberg_works 
  • Facebook:  http://www.facebook.com/erik.aberg.works 
  • Website:  www.erikaberg.com 
  • YouTube channel:  http://www.youtube.com/erik_aberg_works 
  • Viral video from 2014:  www.youtube.com/watch?v=85LJh4sFi_M&t=1s 
  • Twitter: @ghostkube
story_txt:
WHAT IS A GHOSTKUBE?A GHOSTKUBE is a sculpture inspired by moving origami. It consists of cubes connected in a three-dimensional structure. You can manipulate it to change shapes in different ways. It is made from a system of pieces that lock together. When you want to try another design, you simply take it apart and build a different one using the exact same pieces. No matter if you are developing probes for you next Mars mission, constructing skyscrapers, or looking at atomic structures for nano technology, GHOSTKUBES can serve as an inspiration and a tool for creativity. What you see in the film is NOT a 3D printed prototype, it is a finished product from an industrial mold. I wanted to be 100% sure that I could offer a product that worked exactly as I intended. Building and disassembly instructions will be published online.GHOSTKUBE MA-2 can be built with the pieces in the small box. PLEDGE REWARDS IN PICTURESThe GHOSTKUBE comes in Cream White. The KEYSTONE, which is a loose single cube, comes in Moon Gray. Both have a matte finish. Small BoxThis box can build GHOSTKUBES which consist of up to 12 single cubes. Here are examples of what you can build with the pieces in the small box:Examples of GHOSTKUBES that can be built with the pieces in the small box.
 GHOSTKUBE PI-2 can be built with the pieces in the small box.
 GHOSTKUBE MA-2 can be built with the pieces in the small box.
 GHOSTKUBE TF-2 can be built with the pieces in the small box.
 Big BoxThe big box makes it possible to build any two GHOSTKUBES possible from the small box. It can build GHOSTKUBES which consist of up to 24 single cubes. Here are some examples of what you can build with the pieces in the big box:Examples of GHOSTKUBES that can be built with the pieces in the big box.
 GHOSTKUBE TF-6 can be built with the pieces in the big box.
 GHOSTKUBE VH-2 can be built with the pieces in the big box.
 GHOSTKUBE NI-3 can be built with the pieces in the big box.
 GHOSTKUBE MA-3 can be built with the pieces in the big box.
 KeystoneA KEYSTONE is a loose, single cube that you can use to lock a GHOSTKUBE into one position so it will no longer be able to change shape. This is great for display purposes or for adding stability to larger structures. It comes in Moon Gray.A KEYSTONE can be inserted in an extended GHOSTKUBE to lock it into position. It comes in Moon Gray.
 Friend SetThe Friend Set is perfect if you have a friend you want to give a GHOSTKUBE to and you also want to have one for yourself. Or you could just be extra enthusiastic and want to have more options for your own constructions.This set can build GHOSTKUBES, which consist of up to 48 single cubes.The Friend Set contains: 2x GHOSTKUBE big box + 4x KEYSTONEWith two big boxes you can build several GHOSTKUBES and combine them into towers. Example: MA-3, NI-3, KEYSTONE.
 Architect SetIf you want to have several completed GHOSTKUBE designs at the same time, combine them into towers, or build really complex configurations, this is the reward for you.This set can build GHOSTKUBES, which consist of up to 96 single cubes.The Architect Set contains: 4x GHOSTKUBE big box + 6x KEYSTONEExample of three GHOSTKUBES combined to a tower.
  Master Builder SetMaximize the possibilities with this set! I have invented hundreds of variations and will be releasing instructional videos so you will be able to really explore the possibilities of shape changing 3D space and structures.This set can build GHOSTKUBES, which consist of up to 144 single cubes.The Master Builder Set contains: 6x GHOSTKUBE big box + 10x KEYSTONE HOW OLD SHOULD YOU BE / HOW HARD IS IT TO BUILD / HOW FRAGILE IS IT?See it as a plastic model airplane in terms of difficulty and fragility. It is actually not as fragile or as difficult as that, but if that is what you expect, you will be fine. I do not want to make false claims in relation to the expectations for the product or disappoint anyone because they cannot build it. A child might need the assistance of an adult, but could eventually learn to build it without help in a reasonable amount of time. I would probably say that somewhere around 10-12 years old is the minimum age where a child could construct these. The instructions will be in video format, with English as the spoken language. Additional languages or subtitles may be added one day but until then, look at the film to understand what I am doing and follow along to complete your build!TIMELINE
2010 GHOSTKUBE idea
2011 Equipped studio with needed tools
2012 First GHOSTKUBE made in wood
2013 Spent the whole year making them
2014 Viral video on YouTube
2015 Started working on plastic system 
2016 Finding engineers and manufacturers
2017 Prototyping the plastic system
2018 Aug. finished mold
2018 Dec. KICKSTARTER launch
2019 Feb. Indiegogo launch
2019 Feb. design packaging
2019 March make instructional videos
2019 April start manufacturing
2019 June assembly of products
2019 July product delivery starts (six months from the completion of the campaign). 
 DELIVERYWe estimate that delivery will start in July 2019. Many backers will be wanting to give a GHOSTKUBE as a present to their friends or family for the holidays. I know that GHOSTKUBE will make a great gift for Christmas, Hanukkah, or whichever holiday(s) you may celebrate, therefore I have made a printable gift certificate that you can give to your friends to let them know that a GHOSTKUBE is coming their way!CLICK HERE TO DOWNLOAD A PRINTABLE PDF Print or email this gift certificate to the recipient of your gift!
  MANUFACTURINGThe GHOSTKUBE is designed and manufactured in Sweden. It has been patented. SPREAD THE WORDAre you a blogger, a journalist, or just an enthusiast who want to help out?Here is a link to an open Google Drive with exclusive, high quality pictures, and some complementary information about the project for you to use as needed. Feel free to share it as you like! Click this link:PRESS KIT GOOGLE DRIVE  WANT TO SEE MORE?
Instagram:  https://www.instagram.com/erik_aberg_works 
Facebook:  http://www.facebook.com/erik.aberg.works 
Website:  www.erikaberg.com 
YouTube channel:  http://www.youtube.com/erik_aberg_works 
Viral video from 2014:  www.youtube.com/watch?v=85LJh4sFi_M&t=1s 
Twitter: @ghostkube

GHOSTKUBE inventor Erik Åberg.
 Erik Åberg in GHOSTKUBE helmet

story:
REMEMBER TO CLICK ON THE PERKS BEFORE PAYING GUYS!

Introduction/About:

We are a group of college students that love Pokemon gen 4. This year marks the 10th anniversary for Pokemon Diamond and Pearl, and as super devoted Sinnoh fans, we really want to do something special for the anniversary. We decided a zine would be a great way to accomplish this. This is a non profit project; All donations will go to the production of the fan zine!  

As we mentioned before, we are college students and we are broke, so donations will be very VERY appreciated.

What We Need & What You Get

We really need you to donate because:

  • We cannot afford to print out every copy for every participants in the project alone.
  • We want to include more artists/writers, and we can barely afford to include the artists/writers we have now. 
  • All donation goes to the production of the zine, we do not profit.
  • We want to spread the love for gen 4 and including every gen 4 lovers!
We have many different perks, based on different tiers you will get:

  • Keychain
  • Buttons
  • Post card(s)
  • Stickers
  • Legal size print
  • Art prints that will not included in the final book and will not be available in the preorder
  • The physical copy of the zine
  • The more funds we get the more perks we can add!

The Impact

WIth you contribution, we can:

  • Get more artists/writers to join the project
  • That will result in more pages and content in the end product for every reader!
  • Make more bonuses for buyers
  • Spread the love for Sinnoh

Risks & Challenges

Money is our biggest issue; if we don't have enough funds we cannot include as many artists/writers as we would like and cannot print out enough copies.

Other Ways You Can Help

Spread the word!! Tell your friends about this project!!

story:
We are Emily Martian and Kevin Ward, two artists who enjoy drawing insane and weird things. We have decided to join forces and create a book. This book is drawn in both of our styles and features Emily's three filthy cats. We think this book will put a smile on anyone who has a twisted sense of humor and a fondness for those stupid little jerkface furballs we call cats.

This book focuses on Emily’s three Cats: Nommers, Randalls and Motor. We realized that they have not paid rent the entire time they have lived here so it’s time to make them earn their keep. We have created a fun and somewhat adult-humored book. This time around, our book is not exactly kid friendly...unless you're a cool parent who swears a lot. We are excited to show you what kind of trouble these free loaders get into. Our hope is to spread our silliness into the world and make a fun book that people want to pass on and share. We have fingers crossed that this will make it possible to spawn other books, and not just cat books...never mind...just cat books.

We shall call this great piece of work: Pussy Adventure!


What We Need & What You Get

We are looking to raise $1800. This is the bare minimum we need to cover publishing costs as well as the cost of the stickers. We are offering a limited edition run of stickers  and if we are able to exceed our goal by $200 we will create a second high quality indoor/outdoor vinyl sticker of a top secret design which will be added to all those who donate $15 or more. We also hope that we can raise enough to cover Library of Congress registration and copyright costs (currently researching and not included in original goal). To those who donate $30 you will receive a copy of Pussy Adventure signed by Emily and Kevin and will include an original doodle. To those who bless us with a $100 donation, you will receive a full color drawing from both Emily and Kevin.


The book will be 5x7 hardcover with 20-24 pages and will be sent for publishing near the end of the campaign. As for delivery we are at the mercy of the printing company which could take up to 8 weeks but will be shipped to you as soon as we are able.


Both Emily and Kevin are well known artists in the Wilmington, NC community. Kevin has made a career of drawing cartoons of American Presidents and writing books about Folklore. Emily is known far and wide for the creative creatures she makes using watercolor and gouache which often have a silly and somewhat twisted humor.

Other Ways You Can Help

Please donate if able but if you cannot we would truly appreciate any sharing that is done on social media and by word of mouth! It will warm our hearts...well, Kevin's heart. Emily has more of a cold lump of coal.

Meet the Kitties
This is Nommers the psycho...seriously, he's a bi-polar nut job

Randalls who is the most skiddish but lovable weirdo you'll ever meet.

And lastly, the fat one...Motorboat


This is Kevin. He is a very serious person

And Emily who is totally hardcore.

I need to sell a hundred or so of these lil' buggers to get my feet off the ground.

You can pre-order on this indiegogo for $10 for either pin or $15 for both.

story:
Our Story

We have just recently been offered the amazing opportunity to not only go to Miami during Art Basel this year, but to participate by organizing an exclusive group exhibition of some of our finest artists. This is a huge step forward for Subbasement Artist Studios (SBAS), an alternative art space in downtown Baltimore that supports regional emerging artists, to step out into the greater world stage.

To learn more about SBAS, please visit our website sbastudios.com


                         


The Impact

By going to Miami, we will be giving a voice to the artists of Baltimore at the premier art event in the United States.

We will be building an exclusive gallery space in the lobby of the Carlton Hotel in Miami Beach, featuring the four resident artists from Subbasement Artist Studios.


What We Need & What You Get

Due to the short timeline we have to work with, we need to raise an additional $7,500 for the following costs:

// Airfare

// Construction materials (Drywall and studs)

// Lighting

// Art insurance

// Wall paint

// Movers for art transportation

// Signage and labels

// Two hotel rooms for two members of our staff

// Art supplies for live painting demonstration

// Promotional materials


Several exciting perks are available for certain levels of sponsorship:


$10 earns:

A handwritten thank-you from SBAS Director Emeritus Jeffrey Kent and Coordinator Jennifer Tam on a collectable postcard from the 2011 exhibition season.


$100 earns:

Handmade, original paper-cut thank you card, signed by SBAS Director Emeritus Jeffrey Kent, and Coordinator Jennifer Tam


$500 earns:

Handmade, original paper-cut thank you card, signed by SBAS Director Emeritus Jeffrey Kent, and Coordinator Jennifer Tam

One signed original drawing (approx. 18"x24") from a SBAS artist

Two front-row tickets to one of Baltimore-based artist Laure Drogoul's performances (in the upcoming spring 2012 exhibition)


$1000 earns:

Handmade, original paper-cut thank you card, signed by SBAS Director Emeritus Jeffrey Kent, and Coordinator Jennifer Tam

Two signed original drawings (approx. 18"x24") from SBAS artists

Sneak preview and private tour of one upcoming exhibition of your choice

Dinner for two at a Foreman Wolf restaurant in Baltimore, MD

Two front-row tickets to one of Baltimore-based artist Laure Drogoul's performances (in the upcoming spring 2012 exhibition)


$5000 earns:

Handmade, original paper-cut thank you card, signed by SBAS Director Emeritus Jeffrey Kent, and Coordinator Jennifer Tam

Your portrait as an original signed painting (approx. 30"x30") by a SBAS artist

Dinner for two at a Foreman Wolf restaurant in Baltimore, MD

Two front-row tickets to one of Baltimore-based artist Laure Drogoul's performances (in the upcoming spring 2012 exhibition)


Other Ways You Can Help

Every cent counts, so any amount you can donate is greatly appreciated! If you believe in our cause and exposing the Baltimore art scene to an international audience, please help us get the word out by sharing this campaign.

story:
CHECK OUT THE GALLERY FOR SAMPLES OF OUR PAST WORK FOR AN IDEA OF WHAT YOUR DONATION REWARD COULD LOOK LIKE!


DETAILS OF THE PROJECT: The inPrint Collective will be embarking on a four-month exhibition project in partnership with the Scarborough Historical Museum (the SHM), to run from May to August 2012.  While the culmination of our work together will be a show featuring work by members of inPrint and curated by member Kim Dayman, the Collective sees this project as an opportunity to fully engage with a Toronto-based partner in culture such as the SHM that incorporates the on-going production/preservation/interpretation of history while engaging with and contributing to the artistic mosaic of our city. 

The theme of the exhibition is the shared history and the development of ‘memories’ within the Scarborough neighbourhood served by the SHM. The artists of inPrint will organize and participate in a show that explores various conceptualizations of memories, recollections, and changing spaces, negotiating narratives of “the past” as presented and preserved by the SHM. We will create new work that bridges our own personal considerations with the show’s theme, drawing from the rich resources on hand at the SHM. We will be working closely with the Museum’s ‘Community Memories Kiosk’, a project that encourages visitors and neighbourhood residents to contribute stories of their own recollections and experiences of Scarborough, and actively participating in building its history.We will mount the exhibition mainly in SHM's gallery space, seen in our video, but will also present our work throughout the site. As well, inPrint will contribute to the ‘Community Memories Kiosk’ by sharing our experiences working with the SHM, as we make our own mark on the museum. Other sources of insight and inspiration from the SHM will be inspired by the site’s architecture, artifacts and restored gardens.

  COMMUNITY SHARING: As part of our work in integrating this exhibition with the space, we will run a series of printmaking demonstrations at the SHM available to the public as part of their programming. As well, inPrint will be imparting their printmaking skills to the youth volunteer team at the SHM, who can then integrate print projects when they design their art camp programs at the Museum. We hope this skills-sharing will also foster a love of printmaking to the volunteers, who may one day be future members and leaders of the inPrint Collective. 

We see this project as a bridge between fine arts and community outreach. The SHM's mandate is to serve its community, and we believe this project will contribute to that goal.  This show is scheduled to be concurrent with the Museum's celebration of Multicultural Day, in which the Museum will track the site's rich, ever developing history through the lens of immigration.

For more information about the inPrint Collective and to have a look at other projects we've done, check out our website at http://inprintstudio.ca. Past events include demonstrations in the last two Culture Days festivals (2010, 2011), as well as participation in Open Studio's international conference on printmaking, Printopolis (2010). 

WHY WE'RE FUNDRAISING: Part of inPrint's mandate has been to support artists, which includes not only providing exhibition opportunities and skills development but also financial compensation. In order to be able to devote our time to doing this project well, artists have to be paid for their time. Though we are a group of committed artists, we also have to work day jobs in order to fund our practices and pay our bills. Being able to pay artist fees, in accordance to CARFAC, would allow us to take some time off from work to focus on this project properly. We don't expect to sell our work at this exhibition, which is not its major intent anyway, so artist fees would help balance that out. Making art constitutes a lot of labour, and we want to respect that. 

We hope to pay fees in the range of $300 to $500 to each participating artist, for a four month exhibition, which includes public workshops. We anticipate that the costs to mount the show will run us approximately $600. This campaign's goals are only towards a portion of our costs, as we have been actively engaging diverse fundraising projects.

As noted in the video, if we make more then asked for, we'd like to realize a dream for inPrint and publish a catalogue of the exhibition, which would be made available both through the Collective and at the Museum. Catalogues are wonderful documents of temporary shows, and would be a way of preserving our involvement with the SHM for future attendants, as well as providing a space for us to contemplate the themes of the show through the catalogue essay. If we make less than our goal, most of the funds will be allocated to the set-up costs of the show.

DONATION REWARDS: In the higher level donations, we are offering up limited edition work as rewards. Should you donate at this level, we will create limited edition prints inspired by this project just for this reward. A sample of our work is featured in the video, so we hope that whets your appetite for what we're capable of! And we hope you enjoy the prints we've made, just for you!

Can't contribute? That's okay, we'd appreciate a tweet or facebook mention of support towards our cause! IndieGoGo offers a variety of ways to do so--check it out!

story:
Story

I am an artist living in the rural hills of western Massachusetts. I have been making drawings and paintings ever since I can remember. I got my degree in Art History from the University of Denver and taught art in secondary schools to kids with behavioral and learning issues for a number of years. I now garden and restore vintage posters while continuing to pursue my creative path as a visual artist.

This past January while perusing the shelves of a local library I came across a book about textile designs from around the world. I opened the book to a page of Hungarian folk costumes made in the late 1800’s.  The organic designs and bright colors made me gasp with admiration and a sense of deep recognition.  Since that moment, standing there in the library with that book in my hands, I have been on a quest to better understand the imagery found in the peasant and folk arts of Hungary and Poland. In my recent art work I have been exploring these decorative arts and creating images that are inspired by the colors, organic lines, and designs that happen also to be part of my cultural and ancestral background.

How You Can Help.

This July and August, 2011 I am traveling to Poland and Hungary to study the art and folk art of these two countries as well and meet and visit family and friends. I am able to cover half the cost of my study and travel expenses and I need your help covering the cost of the other half of the study program in Krakow and airfare and train fare expenses. This unique quest will unquestionably support my creative growth, development and work as an artist for many years to come.

Study & Travel Plan

I arrive in Krakow, Poland on July 3rd to attend a four week long study program at Jagiellonian University which is the second university to be founded in Central Europe way back in 1364.  The course, which is organized through the Kosciuszko Foundation in NYC, is called "The Art of Poland: Past and Present" and covers the art history of Poland, folk arts, poster art and contemporary art.


While in Krakow I plan to forge a connection with the Ethnographic Museum to do independent study on the folk arts of Poland. I will be taking photographs, sketching ideas and researching images, stories and music that will be influential to my future creations. I’m also very much looking forward to meeting and visiting with my family who reside in and around Krakow, as well as sight seeing to get a glimpse of the culture of my ancestors. Spending time with my family in Poland will broaden my understanding of my family and the culture I come from.


In August I will spend time in Hungary with friends and split my time between Budapest and the countryside. I plan to explore various Hungarian folk/peasant art traditions by visiting museums and attending festivals held on weekends during the summer months. My musician friend wants to share traditional Hungarian music and songs with me as well as put me in touch with traditional dancers who live in his countryside village. I will visit Harskut, Hungary, the village my grandfather's family is from. More photographs, sketches, memories, music and paintings will be made during this time.

The Impact

I believe that there are parallels between the working class people of today and the peasants of yesterday. Instead of toiling for land owning lords we toil for the elite/corporate class. I believe one's connection to meaningful creativity creates spiritual, mental and physical health ultimately fostering a sense connection within oneself and with the outer world by positively impacting community and relationships.

Culturally, I see a shift of interest from a consumeristic mentality to an interest in the cultivation of local economies through the production and consumption of handmade, homegrown products, goods, food and arts. I am interested in traditional cultures and how they created meaning and beauty in their lives before big box stores, factory assembly lines and mass consumption. How were the personal, the spiritual and the beautiful created and shared?

I believe that we find a deeper meaning in life through the creation and appreciation of beauty. I imagine that my ancestors, the peasants of Poland and Hungary, created many things of beauty and meaning despite leading lives full of back breaking work for the benefit of the upper class. Wood working, paper cuts, embroidery, paintings, gardening, music making and story telling gave the peasantry an outlet to create and share stories, folk lore, traditions and beauty. I am looking to re-cultivate this mentality for myself, not only to connect with my personal history but to create homemade things of beauty and meaning, and build new bridges within my community both socially and economically. 

I will create new work to show in community and commercial gallery’s based on my experience. I will share these ideas and what I learn with others through my work and presentations. And I plan to start my own handmade business using my designs.

What I Need & What You Get

All the money you donate goes toward meeting me halfway to cover the cost of the study program and travel expenses.  Any little or big bit helps.  Please look a the "Perks" in the green boxes on the right side of this page to see what I give back to you when you are able to give $10, $25, $50, $100, $300 or more
.
Here is the breakdown of my study and travel costs:
$3600 = cost of study program at Jagiellonian University, dormitory room and three meals a day at the dorm's cafeteria, and weekend sightseeing trips around and outside of Krakow
$1250 = round trip airfare
$150 = one way train ticket to Budapest from Krakow

All money donated will go toward covering these costs and is so very much appreciated.  I will embark on this quest even if I do not meet my fund-raising goal.

Letter of Support and Recommendation

My arts mentor, Valerianna Claff, is a visual arts professor at Clark University in Worcester, MA. She is also the founder of and visionary for the Studio of Mythic and Environmental Arts at RavenWood Forest. She has been very supportive of my creative process this past year and has these kind words to share in support of this campaign and my quest. Thank you, Valerianna!


I have had the pleasure of working with Kim over the past year. A chance meeting in the grocery store led to Kim asking me if I would mentor her in art. A year or so later, I feel honored to witness the growth of Kim’s work – she is clear about what she wants and is deeply passionate about it! It was clear to me when I first saw Kim’s work that she had a wonderful sense of color and design. As her process developed, Kim identified the seeds influencing her work, and found herself studying textile design and folk art from Eastern Europe. Her excitement in pursuing this study was palpable and the work that resulted – a series of paper cuts and textile inspired designs – is quite beautiful. Several months ago, Kim quietly voiced a desire to travel “someday” to Poland and Hungary to study and research  folk art and textiles. In the last month, however, she has exploded into action and found a wonderful program that fits the needs for her artistic exploration perfectly. The quiet voicing of her desire to travel to her roots has given way to strong determination and a grounded knowing that this will be immensely important for her development. I couldn’t be happier to support Kim in this endeavor to meet her financial goals for this trip. Kim’s generosity, kind spirit and dedication to her artistic pursuits – be it singing or visual art – shines, and I have loved working with her.

Valerianna Claff

RavenWood Forest

Studio of Mythic & Environmental Arts

Chesterfield, MA


Other Ways You Can Help

If you know of anyone who may be interested in my quest please share this information with them using the "Share Tools" below. You can also recommend interested people to stop by my blog or facebook page. I'm not opposed to sharing a personal email or phone call with others who are interested as well. Regardless of one's ability to donate, I want to make connections with others who may be interested in these pursuits and topics.

story:
Hi!! I'm Joan from Barcelona, Spain. I'm an illustrator and an electronic musician from the c156 band, working hard to start a small business and enjoying and learning a lot along the way.
The idea of making a vinyl toy was something that was in my head for some time. Although It may seem easy, I have been developing ideas, sketches and prototypes for 4 months, working passionately and hard.
The project began when I started to ask myself if I would be able to accomplish such a complex assignment.
I loved the idea behind the Pop art movement in terms of mass production and affordability, so that "everyone" can have a piece of art in their room. 

For the job, I had to learn many new skills, such as reproduction using silicone rubber molds, casting resin, cnc milling, sanding techniques, 3d prototyping.
I also wanted to follow a strictly D.I.Y approach, saving a lot of money on machine set-ups. So you will see during my updates the two "machines" that I made: A rotocasting machine, and a vacuum chamber.
WHO IS CHUBBYRD?
ChubByrd is the name of the first toy character I made. I like to think of who is he in reality, but I'm pretty sure he enjoys life !!!!



What I Need & What You Get

Although the project is pretty advanced, and going in the direction that I want, there is still a lot of work to do!!
Now I need to start the manufacturing process, this is expensive and time consuming, due the nature of the process itself: I have to make the silicone rubber moulds (using a home made vacuum chamber) and then rotocast this moulds with resin (using a home-made rotocasting machine). This requires a lot of work and time, and the materials are expensive!!



I will also need funding for the packaging, because I'm doing it in the most professional way: offset printing with die-cutting on corrugated cardboard.
This is not an amateur project, you will receive a high quality reward !!!
If you are a fan of art toys, or you simply love design, illustration, comic books... Please help us by sharing this Indiegogo project in your favourite social network, blog, website or just spread the word in the bar whilst sharing a pint with your friends!!!!
Thnx Edu for all the help!!!



Thanks a lot from Barcelona!!


Published in:

http://www.atomplastic.com/2012/02/chubbyrd-by-...
http://www.tomopop.com/help-joan-corral-s-chubb...
http://toysrevil.blogspot.com/2012/02/chubbyrd-...
http://newsodrome.com/gadget_news/chubbyrd-new-...


And don't forget to check out our musical project!!


http://vimeo.com/30873113
